title-group.article-title: Cultural studies and social movements: A crucial nexus in the American case

author-notes.corresp: Jon D. Cruz, Department of Sociology, 3022 Social Sciences & Media Studies Building, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106-9430, USA. Email: cruz@soc.ucsb.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Reflecting on Cultural Studies in the US

abstract.p: Cultural studies took hold in the USA in the context of politics fronted by youth, multi-racial, and gender movements that emerged in the wake of the much larger Civil Rights Movement of the 1960s. With a full-blown academic legitimation crisis well under way, cultural studies resonated strongly with social struggles that shaped both its reception as well as its capacity to augment new intellectual academic formations. Retrieving the historical nexus questions views that treat and limit British cultural studies to being mainly an intellectual import-export phenomenon. The overlooked historical nexus fosters trivialization anad caricature of cultural studies’ incorporation in the American academia, resulting in both conservative antipathy and left disappointments feeding into the common binary narratives of the ‘failure’ of cultural studies for being too Marxist and not Marxist enough. Restoring the historical nexus underscores the value of cultural formations and projects Williams proposed, while cautioning theoreticist and methodological enclosures.

sec.title: A preface of gratitude
sec.p: The article that follows represents a set of reflections that were prompted by interviews published in this issue, which were carried out with Lawrence Grossberg, Andrew Ross, Janice Radway, George Lipsitz and Constance Penley.1 Adding to my motivations were conversations I had with Dick Hebdige, who resonated with the ideas and interests that formed this project. His contribution published here represents a melding of his reflections that look back at this classic study in Subculture: The Meaning of Style and carry forward with shared insights on the contours of his intellectual career. Taken together, I owe a deep gratitude to the individuals who have contributed so generously to the pages that follow this article.

As conceptualized and presented to the editorial board for consideration, this project was to center on interviews with individual scholars who have played a major role in cultural studies – directly, indirectly and ostensibly – in the USA. There were several goals in mind. Using an interview-conversational format, I wanted to capture and document in personal voice the reflections of those whom I interviewed. It was my wish to bring to a larger readership a feel for the personal engagement that these thinkers experienced, along with a recognition that their distinct efforts emerged in the context within which cultural studies was taking hold in the USA. Thus, my purposes were also quasi-documentary, with the intent to chart the interplay of intellectual work and historical circumstances.

Each of the interviews began with an attempt to achieve certain goals. A set of guidelines shaped the interviews. Although the questions varied considerably, I attempted to get at the following horizons: I sought to obtain their reflections of how they began their work as critical intellectuals, so aspects of personal biography were crucially important. It was imperative to get a sense of how they came to see issues, how they struggled in negotiating their way into challenging and confronting what would come to matter to them (and, by extension, cultural studies in the USA). Questions aimed to explore how they came to study and write, the places that shaped their ideas and careers and the initial intellectual problems, theories, issues and currents that they found most challenging. In addition I was hoping to understand better how they built their ideas and work. Reflecting on their own intellectual formations thus opened up the chance to ask them to reflect on work they had carried out, and of their current and future plans. With some of these aspects in front of us, we could proceed to probe particular aspects of their work – ideas, core problems and particular publications. This offered a chance to get at why certain concerns were felt to be central and crucial. This work-specific aspect of the interviews was meant to yield something of pedagogical value to those unfamiliar with such work and useful to newer generation of thinkers in cultural studies. Finally, the last part of the interviews hoped to explore reflection on the current juncture and offered a chance to assess present and unfolding crises and struggles that we ought to confront.

As the interviews neared completion, I began to sketch a short introduction to them. In it I ventured modestly into some issues of contextualization. I shared that first brief draft with my fellow editors – Pertti Alasuutari, Ann Gray and Joke Hermes. It was upon their encouragement and suggestion that I ought to push and expand on what my initial framing was introducing, that the following article came to be written. Without their support and trust in what I might contribute to the readership of this journal, this essay would not have emerged. I am deeply grateful for the stimulation and motivation they have given me and for their intellectual camaraderie that makes such thoughts – and risks – so welcoming.

The article that follows is the result of the interviews – wonderful conversations, actually – with Larry Grossberg, Andrew Ross, Janice Radway, George Lipsitz, Constance Penley and Dick Hebdige, and working with colleague Lisa Parks. Though greatly stimulated by their selfless generosity and seasoned acumen, there should be no assumption whatsoever that what I present below would be automatically endorsed by any of them. However, the careful reader will see in the totality of these pages how, where and to what extent I run with issues and themes that were generated in the interviews, as well as where I venture into additional interpretive terrain.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Cultural studies has been an intellectual enterprise for approximately four decades, and over this period it has achieved significant recognition. Since its inception in Britain in the 1970s it has become a transnational intellectual export finding ground in numerous countries throughout Europe, North America, Latin America, Asia and the Middle East. However, intellectual frameworks do not have fixity like other exports. A material export, such as a garment or car, leaves its home factory and arrives basically as intact as when it left; but such intactness seldom happens with ideas, let alone major intellectual frameworks. When intellectual frameworks travel they leave the fermentation from which they were nurtured, and there is no guarantee that the same mental investments – the historical, social, political and ideological impulses that enabled them to emerge and which are encoded in their form and purpose – will follow them to their next destination. With ideas, some aspects may travel well, while some may not. This is not perplexing; ideas usually change with changing situations. Ideas that are both the impetus for, as well as the culmination of, complex theoretical debates come with strong intellectual investment and a sense of hard-won achievements. It is not surprising that in the process of travel, changes in them can generate strong feelings. Such has been the case with British cultural studies. Ever since cultural studies began to move beyond Birmingham and the Centre for Contemporary Cultural Studies (CCCS), it has had to negotiate transitional engagement with ensuing arguments and reassessments over what it initially was, and what it should or should not be. The process of ongoing debate seems persistent and intractable.

How cultural studies came to intersect social and intellectual developments in the USA is the primary aim of what I shall discuss. In the USA cultural studies has registered in important ways in most of the areas of the humanities and the social sciences, and its impact has been very valuable; yet many retrospective accounts reflect fretting and disappointment. In my assessment, while these views are formed with useful criticism, they overlook or simply occlude the conditions of reception and absorption of cultural studies, and do so by usually focusing on issues that are amplified to the point of crowding out developments which have contributed to the theoretical and analytical strengthening of critical intellectual discourse in the USA. The theoretical expansion that characterized the emergence of cultural studies in general, and the context that enabled it to take hold, deserve reflection and historical appraisal. Cultural studies took hold in the USA in a period in which important intellectual concerns were forged as part of modern social and cultural analysis. It was a period that engaged the articulation of new social movements within a context of much larger social, political and cultural transformations. As I hope to chart, the lessons to be gleaned suggest new questions relevant to cultural studies today.

sec.title: Cultural studies and the export–import model
sec.p: In considering the mix of issues, problems and debates which have emerged in cultural studies in the USA, there appears to be a general and overriding perspective that frames much of what is critically discussed. This perspective begins with a sense of absolute beginnings, with cultural studies having an original theoretical and political impulse. Ensuing from this are various narratives of cultural studies going forth to multiply. This starting point rightly taps into the founding fermentation of cultural studies crucial to its development in Britain. Thus narratives follow cultural studies as it became something of an export item, and from this moment narratives begin to gather a sense of strong disappointment. In making the transition from Britain to the USA, cultural studies was weakened, watered down and the core of its critical spirit dissipated. This view, quite widespread, pivots more so over time on an argument that the importance of class and political economy were emptied out of cultural studies by its new adherents, who focused on cultural terrain and increasingly in ways that spindled the original critical perspective by turning toward problems of trivia and inconsequence – mainly through misguided foci on popular culture. This criticism also hinges on other symptomatic problems that specify serious and intransigent flaws: a view that attributed cultural studies’ dispossession that took place as it became incorporated and commodified, the outcome of accommodating to the pressures of the American university system.

A different but equally disappointed thematic (one shared by the Left and the Right) is a frustration with cultural studies’ initial mode of analysis and intellectual and theoretical orientation. This view orbits around the criticism that cultural studies did not develop and solidify around some recognizable set of methods or approaches. Thus, those sympathetic to cultural studies criticize it for not pushing ahead with more formalized approaches, while those not supportive of cultural studies lambast its lack of methodological formalism and pronounce it dead on arrival. In either case, the view is framed with the notion that methodological maturation, formalism and discipline-like rigor would clear things up and set things right for good. Those who embrace the initial spirit of cultural studies wish to see it operate with more objectifiable practices, methods and purposive consequences (e.g. cultural studies should conduct itself in ways that have allowed other disciplines to evade the crisis of illegitimacy); and those who find no value in cultural studies are quick to write it off. The weakness of cultural studies for not possessing paradigmatic formalism has been core to its criticism, and usually such criticism has been from established disciplines that already stake claims in the study of things cultural.

A further set of criticisms leveled at cultural studies has to do with some of its analytical content (along with methods or lack thereof). In addition to focusing on cultural trivia, these criticisms see cultural studies as floundering on the shoals of identity politics; gender, sexuality and ‘race’ are often implicated as the signifying siren-sites where cultural studies is mislocated and then wrecked. To put it another way, this view operates on the notion that the enterprise’s intellectual property is devalued when inhabited by such concerns – such subject matter is akin to an intellectual residential crisis that houses the wrong inhabitants.

Many of these criticisms come in knotted strands. They have their critical virtues and drawbacks, important insights and blind spots, but they are obfuscating in other ways. Shaped by an intrinsic overreliance on the export view, the problem is attributed either to a good thing gone awry, or to an import flawed from the outset. Both views obscure deeper and engaged developments between cultural studies and the social context in the USA, thus the conditions of engagement deserve to be retrieved. Undoubtedly such views, which are highly evaluative and critical, will sound familiar, and are symptomatic of intense debates. The value of their criticisms, the kinds of arguments that they best serve and the prescriptive work that they propose deserve to be illuminated. With the advantage of hindsight it is possible to identify some of the common views and how they account and mis-account for how cultural studies is understood. As I argue, grasping the conditions in which cultural studies became institutionally engaged requires an understanding of the aggravations within American society that were already in place, or which were being brought into negotiation with cultural studies.

Cultural studies began to have an impact in the late 1970s and early 1980s as it was absorbed into academic disciplines. In what follows, I chart aspects of the American context in which cultural studies was introduced. I take these steps in order to contrast the common and critical views noted above with a perspective that situates cultural studies within an educational context that was deeply engaged in brokering crises that were the result of the Civil Rights Movement, arguably the most important social movement in the USA over the entire 20th century. In taking this approach I hope to highlight two basic problems. First, we need to retrieve an understanding of the installing role that social movements played, enabling cultural studies to take hold in the American context. This view offers an important check on the political neatness that begins with the critique that cultural studies abandoned class – or at least the privileged ontology that class is given in perspectives governed by political economy. While this view has merit, it emerges in ways that fail to acknowledge the cultural prehistory of the deeply racialized antagonisms (which have class-related valences). When this criticism is later grafted on to the juncture in which cultural studies is absorbed, it harbors an unfortunate historical, if not outright political, amnesia. What ensues is an analytical dualism: the historical importance of cultural studies itself is trivialized by this abandonment, while amnesia simultaneously operates to trivialize subjectivity and identity issues that complicate class. As cultural studies is trivialized on the basis of such analytical errors, the arguments that seek to salvage class perspectives revert to the position that cultural studies could be redeemed if it returned to carrying out the older but rigorous approach to political economy and class – as if the theoretical irruption that we have come to know as western Marxism or cultural Marxism, which are so important to the broader intellectual crises that enabled cultural studies to emerge, had never existed. Second, the criticism of cultural studies as a British import that went sour, fell into disrepair, did not arrive intact and lost its way spirit by being contaminated in the American context, deserves to be rethought. This rethinking, I argue, requires that we move beyond the basic framework that begins with a simple ‘export of ideas’ model. What is needed is an exploration of the juncture in which a deeper set of shared historical, political and ideological conditions can be grasped, which help in understanding the issues surrounding how, when and why cultural studies was important to the American intellectual – e.g. academic – context. The routes and developments I examine suggest that the impact of cultural studies has been deeply significant, but this impact has taken the form of remarkable intellectual diffusion. The ‘export–import’ model of intellectual ideas (the dominant perspective) has predisposed many to expect something that cultural studies in the USA could never be: cultural studies failed to materialize into a ‘school’ (or schools and programs) that took on the relative (and reified) appearance of something kindred to the CCCS. While the export model encourages the kinds of perspectives I associate with common criticisms, it actually obscures the ability to recognize the important diffusion-based efficacy that cultural studies has had in the USA.

The common export view of cultural studies has its beginnings in Britain; cultural studies then traveled abroad. The presumptions of the export view runs into problems because the main narrative is locked into a somewhat fixed framework that mimics an older behavioral ‘stimulus → response’ communications model of ‘sender → receiver’. Obvious questions then ensue: how was cultural studies received? What was appropriated? What was modified, or adopted and perhaps distorted? What was ignored or not attended to? In other words, the export model comes with an explanatory grid that is linear and organized around origins and reception. However, the traveling of critical ideas is more complicated. I suggest that the important historical distinctiveness of British cultural studies shares deeper resonating currents with developments in the USA, and that there are good reasons to think through aspects that are constitutive as well as dialogic in a formative and conditional sense. To undo the dominant S–R model, I flag what I think is crucial in understanding the conditions within American society that account for the important value that cultural studies presented; and this has to be understood in relation to the intense and wrenching social movements that threw American society into upheaval. Cultural studies entered the American context in a very troubled and deeply conflicted moment in which the educational sphere was pulled into social antagonisms: it was pressured from below and outside by social groups that made unprecedented demands for inclusion and reform, and from above, to ameliorate and ‘cool out’ social unrest. Cultural studies also registered these developments, yet along different social, cultural and historical valences, as it responded to the larger juncture that enveloped Cold War politics, the solidification of post-war capitalism and the transformation of the entire cultural sphere, especially through the new developments of mass communication. Cultural studies entered the USA in medias res. Thus, my attention focuses on the earlier era of its engagement in the American context. Although there have been numerous recent attempts to propose new directions and challenges for cultural studies, I remain attuned to the historical nexus.

This revisitation does not offer a charting of cultural studies’ institutionalized history or its manifestations within specific departments – a ‘what happened, with whom and where’. Although that story has yet to be carefully told, I am not convinced of its importance. Neither am I interested in defining cultural studies and what it ‘really is’ (as has been repeatedly attempted); this challenge can quickly become as shifting as the various changing narratives which have ‘evolved’ to explain the USA invasion and occupation of Iraq; more generally, it beckons various intellectual enclosures. However, I note some of the principles that are arguably core to some of cultural studies’ founding impulses. I also do not adopt, dwell upon or deploy some of the popular evaluative positions that have become somewhat expected, which characterize critical as well as conservative (or Left and Right) perspectives. These tensions continue on their own.

Yet, not to slight: the critical and conservative views regarding cultural studies do matter, as they constitute many of the parameters and appraisals of cultural studies. On the one hand, there is a critical view that springs sympathetically but unfolds with dismay. Cultural studies is seen as undergoing erosion and losing significance: such developments come with disapproval and disappointment over the shortcomings or outright failure of cultural studies. Such views signal a mix of nostalgia, lament and even betrayal. Cultural studies, it is argued, is no longer the class act that it is supposed to be. The arguments often trot out the reductionist horse that cultural studies was apprehensive to always ride from the outset, even though class concerns often were recognized as crucial. The problem of class was not automatically given the affirmation of a resolute ontology; sometimes other cultural factors could be more salient in accounting for things, and this meant that historical openness could yield social dimensions that might trump the view of class as the alpha and omega of social analysis. From this view, cultural studies was not Marxist enough.

On the other hand, the conservative criticism of cultural studies pivots on the argument that the enterprise was too Marxist from the start. It began flawed, with the basic mistake of embracing the New Left and western Marxism. This more conservative criticism indicted cultural studies for its intellectually genetic, and thus chronic, confusion. Cultural studies was tarnished further by its undisciplined disregard for the history of established disciplines, whose simple existence and duration within academe was justification enough. Furthermore, each perspective held the view that cultural studies lacked a firm position, a committed method and far too much willful embrace of indeterminacy.

The irony is that both perspectives have some traction, but not enough to move ahead. Cultural studies did not embrace uncritically the received ontologies of orthodox Marxism and the attendant analytic schemas of a narrowed political economy. Lukacs’ interrogating probe, which problematized economic reductionism, suggested that the very notion of ‘orthodox Marxism’ was an oxymoron – especially with regard to how it promoted a formalist and ahistorical mode of analysis. Such criticisms were amplified in Gramsci’s writings, as he extended the critique of Marxist Party fondness for a positivist scientism that flirted with its own misrecognized theology. The unfinished challenges that signaled possibilities for complicating mechanistic approaches within Marx’s initial project, presented in the Introduction to the Grundrisse, became key to Stuart Hall’s (1974) important probes. Yet if cultural studies was too Marxist or not Marxist enough, it was because it took Marx seriously. It was impelled to engage with ensuing theoretical debates surrounding western Marxism and cultural Marxism, enough so to insist that the crises of capitalism, class and economy were crucial, but had to be reconciled with the rupturing problem of the cultural, and that this was not rendered simply by recourse to a priori resolution in theory or method. Not Marxist enough or too Marxist: both are scenarios that have grown over the last four decades to indict cultural studies for not being amenable to discipline. Cultural studies was successful in presenting a much-needed alternative to disciplinary rigidity, the source of its strength and continual ability for renewal. Yet it drew attacks for its failure to promote a sense of discipline and its anti-disciplinary posture. From the outset, cultural studies harbored the irony by having to work with this Janus-faced profile. It was caught in powerful crossfire. This has not changed.

sec.title: Projects and formations: the framework reassessed
sec.p: Before turning to the American assimilation of cultural studies, I want to retain some of the challenges, issues, problems and conflicts that marked its inauguration in Britain. Even though four decades have passed, many of the formative issues remain relevant today. Holding in play early formative (and shared) problems alongside unique developments, as can be seen in the American case, helps to underscore distinctions and continuities that illuminate larger histories that tend to be overlooked.

Time engenders development and sometimes development breeds its own notions of moving things forward, of some kind of progress. Considering the intellectual and historical crossing and meshing of issues that spurred cultural studies into being in the first place, we might wonder: what of its legacy remains vital? Of its various theoretical engagements, which are still important? What has been resolved? Are there certain problems that remain intractable or naggingly recalcitrant? What can afford to be forgotten? What lessons have been learned or are still in need of being learned – or simply retrieved – as cultural studies continues to be voiced as an important intellectual enterprise? These questions have been, and continue to be, asked in a variety of ways and with regard to the various sites of cultural studies’ absorption and practice. Rehearsing things past is always a wager on and a claim to relevance. However, remembering also checks the rush to move things along (to advance cultural studies or to dismiss it); it pauses to consider things that are subject to forgetting. Forgetting can be strategic and intentional, with older ideas discarded for newer ones. But remembering seems crucial in this case, and is an antidote to the pitfalls of a presentism (the forgetting about formations, as warned by Williams) that pushes full speed ahead with emptied memories and a full tank of amnesia. The willful chant to just ‘get on with things’, sometimes for reasons more costly than profitable, is not always an intellectual virtue, although there is an air of it being so. As critical thought moves forward in high gear, eager to leave the past behind, there are times to pause, take stock of baggage shed or things gained, and of the things to hold on to. This, I think, applies to the case with regard to cultural studies more generally, its adoption in the American context more particularly, and its movement forward from the earliest moments to ongoing strategies for thinking it into the present.

I find it helpful to recall passages from Raymond Williams written shortly before his passing, in which he reflected on what might lie ahead for cultural studies. His remarks flagged what he felt was core to cultural studies, which was not a definition so much as a challenge that made cultural studies possible:
I want to begin with the quite central theoretical point which to me is at the heart of cultural studies but which has not always been remembered in it and this is – to use contemporary terms instead of the rather more informal terms in which it was originally defined – that you cannot understand an intellectual or artistic project without also understanding its formation; that the relation between a project and a formation is always decisive; and that the emphasis of cultural studies is precisely that it engages with both, rather than specializing itself to one or the other [as this requires] the refusal to give priority to either the project or the formation.

This was the ‘crucial theoretical intervention’ that constituted cultural studies. However, this very intellectual and analytical framework also applied to cultural studies itself:
We have to look at what kind of formation it was from which the project of cultural studies developed and then at the changes of formation that produced different definitions of that project. We may then be in a position to understand existing and possible formations which would in themselves be a way of defining certain projects towards the future. (Williams, 1989: 151–152)

The statement appears simple and cogent: hold on to the necessary and productive tension between a project and its formation – but this has proven to be enormously difficult, especially if dealing with complex modes of thought that also move from one social context to another. Projects may change in their new settings. The formation that initially mattered may not be so formidable in another context; a qualitatively different formation may eclipse an earlier one. Numerous attenuating circumstances make this task immediately complex. Yet, having a sense of bearings is the constant requirement, as formations never come neatly packaged or simple to unwrap. There is always some kind of starting point in carrying out this principled approach, and it too is likely to be interpretively contentious.

For starters then: cultural studies emerged out of the post-war/Cold War, mid-century upheavals in which major transnational political and ideological realignments were in movement. It is no accident that the primary theoretical axes with which cultural studies felt compelled to work were associated with a modernity that was adjudicating the larger tensions of the Marxian legacies: the nation-state orthodoxies; the new arcs of transhistorical forces; the various irruptions within Marxism that took form as ‘western’ and ‘cultural’ Marxism; and wrenching efforts to grasp and understand the fractures and reconsolidations of mid-20th-century capitalism. Cultural studies also inherited the major issues of the old Left and the New Left, but it was the new and newly-available theoretical productivity associated with the New Left that enabled cultural studies to emerge and flourish (Gray, 2007; Hall, 1990). The installing work of key founders such as Raymond Williams, E.P. Thompson and Richard Hoggart can be read as particular attempts to work with these political inheritances and merge them with new theoretical contributions. To state things so generally is already sufficient to sense a context so ripe for refracting intense conflicts across the spheres of social and political theory. With its inaugural intervention into the theoretical, political and social problems in contemporary British society, cultural studies struggled to comprehend, take stock, address and critique the debates on how to grasp the problem of culture. This required engaging a host of interpretive frameworks, including but not limited to the Marxian theoretical legacy, traditional and critical theory within the ongoing economic irruptions of an advancing capitalism, the legacies of inherited ideologies, the characteristics of the social formation – and, of course, persistent questions of class, but quickly after its inception, made more complicated by racial and ethnic diasporas and an increasingly pressing recognition of gender – and all this unfolding against an omnipresent and pervasive mass-mediated culture.

Beyond exploring theories, the CCCS sought its own arenas of interpreting the moment’s inheritance and demands. It mobilized students and faculty, it launched studies, it published papers and monographs, it literally intervened in the academy’s epistemological order of things while it simultaneously experimented with pedagogy. It posed ways of rethinking the knotty relations that manifested as culture and culture’s embeddedness with the problems of how history, social formations, economies, politics, ideologies and regimes of power were complicit in, and constitutively involved, the sprawling terrain of institutions and the state. In so doing it disordered, disembedded, dislocated and unsettled erstwhile grids of explanation; it pushed hard, consistently and consciously on the logics and boundaries of established knowledge formations.

By willingly occupying such a nexus of tensions, cultural studies had to have a particular audacity and verve for without such, cultural studies would likely have withered, perhaps not even leaving a trace of something striving to be born. One such major impulse was the willingness to traverse established knowledge formations and to reject disciplinary fidelities in exchange for transdisciplinary interrogations and appropriations. It is not surprising, then, that it was met with a range of responses that ran the gamut from strong endorsement to purging punishment. Thus on the one hand, cultural studies offered a much-needed breath of fresh air, rekindling life into a moribund and ossified body of social thought, and enabled a reinvigorated sense of theoretical and political relevance to bear upon the new social and cultural formations of contemporary life. On the other, it was castigated as being wrong-headed, fostering (un)intellectual naivete, a thorn in the side of those who felt that they had earned their professionalized walks in life and were not to be tripped up by unleashed interlopers trespassing upon sanctified intellectual property. Cultural studies found fans and enemies. Thus the gamut of responses to cultural studies ran along expected lines.

Historical narratives and recollections of the founding years have been written along the way, and there are no shortages of documents that capture aspects of this important intellectual development. They range from brief and personal anecdotes to intense recall of various kinds of engagements, to biographical profiles. The composite sets of images that have emerged are just as passionate and varied, as are the responses to the terrain of issues and ideas that cultural studies attempted to confront, and for so many social and historical reasons. There are those actual sensibilities of carrying out the work, which take the form of testimonials to critical awakenings, of war stories and accounts of battle scars, of problems opened and closed, of intensely partisan orbits around particular issues, as well as a keen feel for inhabiting the shifting ground between institutional collusion and collision. Many of Stuart Hall’s writings convey the complex challenges of work carried out in complicated milieus, for Hall has been exceptionally eloquent in reflecting analytically on the steps that merged problems and questions, clarifying the historico-theoretical terrain that shaped and governed unavoidable perspectives and discourses, and stating the urgent stakes involved in the very act of intellectual and analytical engagement. Many others who have reflected on cultural studies have continued to inhabit such tensions; hence the frequent and valuable accounts that impart a unique sense of selves involved and engaged in intellectual horizons that enabled the grasp and synthesis of some of the most important social, cultural, political and theoretical dialogues of the era.

The sprawl of observations and accounts and the sense of investment and commitment – as well as the external opposition to cultural studies – are understandable. They also share in the constitution of cultural studies. More a verb than a noun, the notion of cultural studies as an intellectual project, conceived here in this broadest and fundamental sense, meant that it was not a readied formalist paradigm. Indeed, the contrast between these two orientations was provocative as well as antagonistic, and it remains so today. It is difficult to hold on to with ease the notion of a project that strives (in this case) to operate with an openness to the interplay of theory and politics, that tries to work at a transdisciplinary level, that seeks to hold on to a historically attuned flexibility of sentiment and sensibility while struggling in the discrete moments of living on the ground, as it were – since living day-to-day always feels much more a condition than a project. The appeal of formalization and paradigmatic order certainly offers comfort if it produces a sense of feeling in possession of (or feeling compelled to normalize ourselves to) models and paradigms, for they offer guidance and procedures and keep things in check (and are rebuffed as well as rewarded).

Project or paradigm? Sensibility or system? Informed indeterminateness or formalized certainty? It is not surprising that many of the ensuing debates around cultural studies, especially as it gained transnational mobility, would center on the inherent tension between the notion of project as a theoretical and political sensibility and the impulse to encapsulate things into a program and paradigm that could be grounded in selective issues, questions and notions of method: what enables smooth entry into the trade of institutional currencies. Thus the gamut of views always abound. Certainly, cultural studies endured the shifting fate of an enterprise with intense commitments on its behalf, but also vituperative diatribes celebrating its faults, if not failures. The tensions intrinsic to project and program are rooted in attempting to tack back and forth between them, which Williams saw as fundamental. To the extent that cultural studies is a project, it inherits this condition. Moving back and forth between these two positions, straddling them if possible, required one foot in the project and the other in a program. How well or problematically this is carried out offers a way to read historical accounts as well as the current diagnostics and prognostics of cultural studies, past and present.

sec.title: Brokering abroad: initiating challenges and dilemmas
sec.p: Delving into the knotty peculiarities of the American case requires that we keep in mind strands of commonality and exchange that were important in both the British and the American situations (and perhaps having some relevance to other situations). Some of these shared ties appear to be lost – indeed, they may not have been important or even perceived – in the rapid assimilation, or talk thereof, of cultural studies becoming ‘incorporated’ into the academy, along with a host of appraisals regarding the virtues and drawbacks that this intellectual development entailed. I pause to reflect on the so-called ‘incorporation’ moment in order to retrieve relations that raise and sharpen issues that bear on evaluating projects and programs falling under the rubric of cultural studies.

As cultural studies was being resisted in Britain, it began to flourish abroad, gaining traction in new contexts willing and able to absorb it, even though the recognized unsettledness intrinsic to its formative framework remained. In the American case the adoption and adaptation of cultural studies was met with both appreciation and consternation. However, there was the added conflict among those committed to cultural studies that involved debates shaped by the process of cultural studies moving from Britain to other settings (I will return to this below). There were –and remain – many who rejected and dismissed cultural studies outright, as was the case with its inception in Britain. Nonetheless, there was a markedly broader willingness to host cultural studies in the American academy, a sharp contrast to the case in Britain. In the American context cultural studies could find new traction, although there were many who (and who still) viewed it with a jaundiced gaze emanating from the gatekeeping work of traditional disciplines and paradigms. As a CCCS-centered enterprise, cultural studies’ key disposition toward transdisciplinary work could emerge in concentrated form through its working papers. The array of writings affiliated with the CCCS and its intensity of mission, shifting urgencies, theoretical engagements and accommodations to ongoing as well as emergent projects were published as stenciled papers and working papers. Fortunately, many of these papers from the CCCS’s archives have been republished, some for the first time, which now give us access to the range of problems taken up in work generated there (Gray et al., 2007). Given its highly centralized operation, the migration of cultural studies to the diffuse context of the USA would immediately alter its identity as an intellectual project.

It was not surprising that the application of cultural studies to other contexts would involve appropriations that shared many of CCCS’s interests. The nexus of theory and politics that Hall identified in the inheritance of ‘old’ and ‘new’ theoretical discourses were just as much a vibrant tradition in the USA, and rooted in an already heated legacy of social moments. Yet, there were different conflicts in the USA that resonated with the uneasy relationship between intense civil strife and academe. Thus, the appropriation of cultural studies would develop attachments to different problems, questions and interests. As to be expected, there was strong debate about the origins of cultural studies, its relevance and adaptability. While predictably, traditional disciplinarians fretted over cultural studies, those who embraced it vented frustration with the notion that cultural studies was being weakened, watered down, even betrayed and defiled, its political importance withering to become merely another academic enterprise. As it was appropriated by and applied in new and different contexts, others argued that cultural studies was never meant to be rigidly interpreted and reified into a paradigm or school, that it was never constructed to be one thing, and so moving to another social context inevitably would entail transformation. Yet, it also could be expected that cultural studies would continue to expand its challenge, to unsettle presumably settled views and disciplinary comforts, while also lending itself to various applications that could ran the gamut from intellectual query to concrete political struggles. By the early 1990s cultural studies had hosted a broad set of topics, problems and interests as it proliferated in new contexts – but not as a body of readily compatible ideas, problems or approaches. Debates and contentions aside, such diverse perspectives also underscored the new contributions that cultural studies could make to both academic and non-academic concerns.

In the American context it is helpful to flag two quite important publications that capture well the period in which cultural studies began to be recognized as having taken hold, for better or worse. I do so not to mark textual origins for cultural studies, but rather to illustrate the presence and transitory qualities of certain intellectual strands that coexist as contextually significant. In both cases, the publications mark important and multiple lines of force (socially rooted developments) and thought (theoretical engagements) that enable such documents to emerge (as symptoms rather than causes). In summer 1983 a large conference was convened at the University of Illinois. Many of its presentations were published in Marxism and the Interpretation of Culture (Nelson and Grossberg, 1988). A second conference held in spring 1990, also at the same institution, reflected a more focused orientation to cultural studies per se. These presentations and contributions were published in Cultural Studies (Grossberg et al., 1992). Eight years passed between these two conferences, yet both documents reflect in distinct ways the discovery, assimilation and tensions over what cultural studies could or could not, or should or should not be in the American context. I reflect on these two publications because they signal important moments in the assimilation of cultural studies into the American academy.

Marxism and the Interpretation of Culture represents a deep engagement with the sympathetic yet critical relationship with Marxism, centering often on the challenge and need to overcome the separation of culture from social, political and economic relations. In this regard, the period of the early 1980s marked an ever-widening appraisal of critical thought which had moved along multiple fronts and beyond an older orthodoxy of a hermetically privileged approach to political economy. The tensions that manifested in the new critical spirit were not new; indeed, they had been well underway since the mid-century, and were taking shape in the post-war political atmosphere that grew in intensity with the deepening of the Cold War and concomitant struggles involving geopolitical realignments that were emerging in both East and West. Many of the theoretical reassessments centered on a ‘troubled’ Marxism (rooted mainly in notions of orthodoxy and its discontents) and a growing and concerted need to ‘trouble’ Marxism (interjecting problems into orthodoxy that demanded inclusion and rethinking – e.g. culture). There were problems within an older legacy of Marxism increasingly viewed as having become ossified theoretically and inflexibly encased in nationalist applications; there were implications in theory as well that were recognized as having been sidelined and muted; and there were historical developments linked to new formations as well as additionally complex spheres of subjectivity. These and other problems culminated in a host of new problems which had to be brought to Marxism and the extent to which Marxian theory did or did not offer meaningful accounts. These debates involved issues that had simmered for decades, and many of them irrupted as core concerns of an emergent western Marxism or cultural Marxism. Many of these concerns were duly noted on many occasions within the theoretical challenges that informed British cultural studies, precisely because they were being transposed onto terrains of everyday life, thus becoming currents in both academic-centered intellectual struggles and manifested in the subjects and objects of new critical enquiry. Thus the nexus of problems being honed in Britain offered possibilities of a cultural studies relevant to USA thinkers, who also registered the historical ruptures brought in by mid-century social upheavals that bookended the Cold War era. The writings registered in the 1983 proceedings which culminated in Marxism and the Interpretation of Culture offer a sense of the juncture in which British cultural studies became relevant in the USA and in the context of new theoretical ruptures.

Yet it is interesting to note that in the 1983 proceedings, the editors flagged ‘cultural practices’ (not cultural studies) as the provocative terrain that required exploration. Contributors to the edited volume represented a rather remarkable transnational sprawl of intellectuals, theoreticians and cultural practitioners, each offering provocative reflections on a wide range of issues, but having some bearing on the emergent and urgent problem of culture. The proceedings also captured the sense of something breaking into visibility, a recognition of a larger and shared notion that intellectual business as usual – from an ossified Marxism to entrenched academic disciplinarity – was woefully inadequate to confront the new junctures, and that new possibilities of thought and practice were plausible and necessary. Many of the presentations, as did the conference as a whole, refracted the larger intellectual currents that were being accommodated within social and cultural theory, especially the widespread critiques of economic reductionism and the cultural crises – or the crisis of culture – within Marxian theory. It was a period in which the legacy of the Soviet Union was undergoing political transformation under the glasnost movement, while neo-conservative politics in the West (pushed especially by the USA and Britain in the Reagan–Thatcher alignment) was in ascendancy. In addition, theoretical developments were undergoing major reconsideration, with the emergence of critical assessments of representation championed by poststructuralism, deconstructionism and postmodernism. These theoretical impulses were never rigid and autonomous, as they were often critically engaged, sometimes caustically and irreconcilably, with Marxian theory. Moreover, these intellectual incursions were joined by the growing tensions that sprung from new (or perhaps the return of repressed) social subjectivities, especially expressed in feminist and racial forms of identity theorizing, with each developing and expanding upon larger and important aspects of problems of culture. Taken as a whole, the writings in Marxism and the Interpretation of Culture present the flash of issues opening onto multiple fronts, each demanding to be critically fathomed, if not integrated. The perspectives also convey the provocation that intellectual work was quickly moving beyond staid disciplinary confines, and opening up to increasingly urgent needs of exchange and risk.

The follow-up conference, which took place several years later and was captured in 1992 in Cultural Studies, remained equally stimulating and provocative with its wide range of contributors. However, unlike the proceedings from the first conference, the term ‘cultural studies’ became a central object of intense concern and took on the notion of something potentially objectifiable – which also meant that it (whatever it was) could be wrestled over. The modes of objectifying and questioning cultural studies also served as grounds to object to as well as affirm. The title of the publication highlighted the significance of British cultural studies’ incorporation into American critical discourse. As a dominant intellectual thematic, cultural studies was realized as having traveled to social, historical, cultural and political sites different from its inception in Britain. It was being carried out and in many sites, although nowhere was it centralized as it had been in Birmingham. What it was, what it ought to be and what was happening to it, along with many questions of its intellectual and political fate, were subjected to strong debate. In 1990 Stuart Hall had written an important critical reflection on cultural studies in which he reiterated earlier positions on the juncture of history and intellectual formation. In that writing, he noted how cultural studies in Birmingham was not the only way to do cultural studies: cultural studies ‘has been ever since, an adaptation to its terrain; it has been a conjunctural practice. It has always developed from a different matrix of interdisciplinary studies and disciplines’, and even in Britain the ‘three or four places bold enough to say they are offering courses in cultural studies have different disciplinary roots, both in the humanities and the social sciences’ (Hall, 1990: 11). Hall’s assessment actually was refracted in the contentiousness over what to make of cultural studies as it moved into different social and theoretical spaces.

The insurgent growth and mobility of cultural studies could not help but conjure difficulties in relating origins with new applications. As a publication, cultural studies signified this new juncture. The edited volume is a valuable document, yet a selective archive, of views within or significantly related to cultural studies. It presented a broad range of perspectives but also served as a sphere attracting fierce arguments over the identity and fate of cultural studies, the problems that it engaged and the issues and fronts that remained major challenges. The contributions throughout Cultural Studies illustrate numerous attempts to reposition and restate the stakes in cultural studies. John Stratton and Ien Ang (1996), in a telling manner, also criticized the book in another edited book (devoted to Stuart Hall), arguing for a rethinking of cultural studies in relation to reconceptualizing a subversive subalternity. They acknowledged cultural studies as a tour de force, but then quickly noted its largess (800 pages, 40 papers and derived from a conference attended by some 900 people). In Stratton and Ang’s account, the value of cultural studies rapidly evaporated; it transformed into the grotesque. The book was described as ‘monstrous’ and a failure as a ‘map’: ‘Just like Frankenstein’s unnamed larger-than-life creation, Cultural Studies is an excessive book.’ The book was then equated by analogy through another analogy – a quote from Borges is deployed, which refers to how an overdrawn or wrongly drawn cartography can be woefully distorting. Cultural studies was reduced to a bad map that would fall into disuse for its inherent ‘Platonic formulations of representation’ (Stratton and Ang, 1996: 363).

The temptation to draw up cartographies based on assessing the holdings of an archive – an edited book in this case – is always seductive. Stratton and Ang sought to uncouple cultural studies from its historically formative moments, acknowledging its spreading (transnational) influence and how such developments raised the ‘impossibility of a global cultural studies’ navigable by one dominant map. This appeared to be a reasonable move: in essence, it reiterated Hall’s argument, but Stratton and Ang’s review pivoted toward a different motivation: a search for a subversive subaltern. What subject? Where to find? Stratton and Ang then argued that ‘the most subversive “international” cultural studies rendez-vous was held in Taipei, Taiwan in 1992’ (Stratton and Ang (1996): 386; emphasis added) and represented the ‘first international cultural studies conference in a non-western context’. From this they concluded to ‘characterize the position of “Taiwanese” cultural studies in relation to all versions of western cultural studies as subaltern’ (p. 387). Aside from staking out moves of re-authentication, the thematic pitched in this case is a concern for where intellectual meetings take place. The proposition might strike one as reminiscent of an older spirited debate once vibrant but now dormant in Marxism: the problem of actually existing socialism. In this case the problem appeared to be aimed at pinpointing an actually existing subaltern conference location.

There are reasons to be critical about ideas that emerge in one setting but are applied to different contexts, as problems of dislocation and relocation do alter meanings. However, similar problems emerge in the moves suggested in locating subalternity, and here we need to pause on the problems involved when critical terminology is transposed from one setting to another. The term ‘subaltern’ is an informative example of why we should pay attention not just to theoretical and programmatic transpositions, as is the case with British cultural studies traveling ‘abroad’, but also to the way in which terms are disconnected and redeployed, for what purposes and with a sense of what new traction is gained or lost. There is nothing intrinsically easy or neat about theorizing that aims to reconstitute the meaning of subaltern, and it is reshaped in postcolonial frameworks for identifying, tracking and grasping what accounts for positionally fixed or diasporically dislocated subjects in relation to conceptualizations of power that serve as the operational definition of subalternity. Subalternity subjected to diasporic forces (movement of subjects and subject matter) is complicated by an ontology of origins (national, geographic, ethnic, racial, etc.) inherent in both terms. Subjects (which in this case, include people, intellectual theories and projects) that are subjected to diasporic forces and conditions that result in mobility (forced or willed) are presumed to have begun somewhere, to be going somewhere, to land somewhere; and they may be subjected to constant dislocation (perhaps traveling in ways that are not just material, spatial or geographic, but even ideological and psychic). Thus transformations (including the impact on identity, making the latter fluid) happen in movement – which can be extended and applied to theories and politics (much like what the history of ideas or intellectual histories have long suggested) – which is the case for subaltern as a term.

However, as an edited book, Cultural Studies is fundamentally a collection of ideas, a moment of writings that refract ideas of conference attendees and emanated from a gathering in the USA which, in itself, would accrue its own particular problems. It is not a map; if anything it is a historically momentous archive, open of course to questions of representation, and in its moment and on its pages, we see cultural studies taking on a broad range of sensibilities which are intensely debated. If one sought and wanted order, direction and paradigmatic neatness – or a better venue for subalternist validation based on new and better subject-positioning, and all the re-theorizing that such a move implies – this was not to be found in this text. In his review, Frederick Jameson summed up the text, not as a map with its virtues and limitations, but as symptomatic of a particular desire.

If Cultural Studies was flawed in ways presumably rectified by relocating discourses outside the West, American sociologists of culture rejected both this text and British cultural studies as a field of analysis, not because of a failed mapping that warranted redrawing, but because it failed ‘in its professed goal’. According to these sociologists, the major flaw was not in its being too western; it was western enough. What it lacked was proper intellectual accents. More precisely, cultural studies had the wrong western accents: it was overly Marxian, and this was measured by neglecting the inclusion of American cultural sociologists rooted in Weberian and Durkheimian paradigms. The problem, it was argued, is that ‘Neo-Marxist strands of British and French cultural studies’ come with an insularity that excludes ‘the large and impressive body of work by sociologists as DiMaggio, Griswold, Wuthnow and Lamont’, as well as ‘Wagner-Pacifici, Zarubevel, Alexander and Seidman’. What is immediately noteworthy about these named sociologists is that they are identified by their corresponding insularity from Marxism: they represent ‘not only the distancing [in their work] from Marxist language but also a much stronger emphasis on the relative autonomy of cultural actions and meaning systems’ (Sherwood et al., 1993: 374). In short, these American sociologists were cast as offering a viable double-move: to get away from Marxism and to get at culture’s ontological and autonomous foundations, and with this came an objective or objectivizing grasp of the autonomy of culture. Interestingly, we are presented here with a mirror of ontologically oppositional inversions: Marxism’s flaw in positing the autonomy of economy is rectified by positing the autonomy of culture. This kind of dualism and dichotomization was precisely what the more theoretical reflections in cultural studies often addressed and sought to get beyond.

Whether finding redemption by relocating beyond the West, or erring by ignoring core figures in western sociology, these juxtaposed views each posit their own distinct issues regarding cultural studies as it found its way out of Britain and into new appropriations and critiques. Both cases highlight quite oppositional tendencies while attempting to reset theorizing and approach and posing their own notions of what is at stake and how to move ahead. While emanating from quite different intellectual perspectives, both illustrate an impulse to purge wrong-headedness and secure a new coherency; both seek some variation of re-theorized and re-disciplined thought, along with presumably fine-tuning the proper analytical enclosures and situated definitions that might bring one closer to an acceptable feel for what is preferred epistemologically.

To return to cultural studies’ moves abroad: the examples raised thus far begin to signal the growing complexity and contention that cultural studies would invariably encounter in and beyond the West. They are symptomatic but not exhaustive of the new complexities. However, what interests me is not the problem of bad cartography or the neglect of the core figures within a discipline’s subfield. Whether we dwell on an edited book or an intellectual sphere, I do not wish to suggest, as do many of its embracers or detractors, that cultural studies has had a monopoly on wheel-spinning, ideational sprawl while moving along in a parade of problems and probes, characterized by irreconcilable arguments, incommensurabilities, wrong starting points or wrong conclusions – that is the stuff of open discord fueled by various analytical comfort and preferred approaches.

As for sociology, often considered deeply kindred to cultural studies (Inglis, 2007; Morley, 2007), it is instructive to note what Randall Collins, a leading American sociologist, had to say about the discipline around the time that cultural studies was entering the American intellectual horizon. According to Collins, sociology had absolutely no sense of core or center. His view is valuable to quote at length:
The deepest part of our intellectual malaise, then, is due to crises in the making of intellectual careers today. Wide recognition of intellectual accomplishment seems so much less likely to happen; persons who are elevated – either through the publishing business, the electoral process of professional associations or the vagaries of college reading lists – can only satisfy the intellectual alliances of comparatively small parts of the total intellectual field and hence seem illegitimate to adherents of other specialties. Mathematical sociologists, historical Marxists (and non-Marxian historical sociologists, nonhistorical Marxists, etc.), phenomenologists, analysts of contemporary social problems, organizational researchers and others seem scarcely to recognize the names of the eminent practitioners in specialties other than their own. There are no longer rival theories and alliances within a single intellectual field; instead, we have become congeries of outsiders to each other, unable to see what the rivalries actually are in other fields and hence prone to view the statements of those whose names do ‘accidentally’ stick up above the watermark as arbitrary and meaningless. Hence the vituperation that permeates our intellectual life today, when members of one subfield look out at the specialties beyond. (Collins, 1986: 1340; emphasis added)

It would be a mistake to think of Collins’ observation as out of date. At the risk of humor, it is tempting to compare Collins’ description of sociology with the painstaking attempts in some of the best aspects of early British cultural studies, where there were unique moves to embrace, interrogate, compare, contrast and merge various theoretical traditions – from Marx’s writings to Marxism’s ‘cultural’ and ‘western’ packages; semiotics, literary theory, structuralism and poststructuralism; media and communication theory and studies, subcultural and deviance or criminology theory. When one looks at a weighty collective work such as Policing the Crisis (Hall et al., 1978) as an intellectual project, and in contrast with Collins’ description of sociology, Policing the Crisis demonstrates what sociology would appear to lack: a highly unusual sense of necessary intellectual integration and corresponding gravity, even as it engages in disparate and far-flung problems. Moreover, cultural studies practitioners were generally in conversation – even though at times they were at each other’s throats (Hall, 1990; Johnson, 1997). In contrast, sociology in Collins’ view appears to be something like a Tower of Babel or of prisoners happy in solitary confinement, who have their niche beyond which little more matters. More important to note is that Collins’ inside view of entrenched sub-specialization is not sociology-specific; it resonates accurately in many disciplinary fields. After all, it is in the spirit of academic professionalization to pursue the twin paths of specialization and area demarcation. Moreover, as with other disciplines, sociology is well capable of harboring quite discrepant interpretations on this account: Weber would flag this as a moment in modern rationalization; Durkheim would note the expanded competition within an intellectual discipline as a case of moral density that is likely to produce a presumably appeasing segmentation and subdivision; and Lukacs would indict the reification of specialized knowledge fields as a symptomatic refraction of modernity’s relentlessly competitive commodification manifesting in intellectual work itself. Collins’ criticism is not about things mysterious, given how the reward structures within intellectual fields come with an incessant march along paths of a rationalized division of intellectual labor, pivoting on the expertise that champions the realm of things demarcated and discrete and constructing walled-in systems of specialist recognition. Rigorous focus comes with license to ignore the problems that are conveniently screened out and beyond the pale of favored cases, sites, theories and methods. Nonetheless, given Collins’ description of sociology and the period of observation, it is ironic that many practitioners of sociology (and other fields in the humanities and social sciences) at this very time were quick to indict cultural studies as having nothing to say, or of speaking with the wrong analytic accents, or worse yet, trapped in bedlam and flirting with the seduction of the innocent who would follow the new Pied Pipers.

Even in their sprawl, the tenor and fretting in the probes and positions reflected in the pages of Cultural Studies were provocative – unnervingly so. They also embodied many of the tensions noted in the earliest accounts of the CCCS’s formative years, but now they were occurring beyond Britain and were being writ large, as cultural studies was brokered upon an increasingly larger terrain of actors, institutions and contexts. Moreover, inverse relations appeared to take hold: as cultural studies moved outward and encountered new contexts and an ensuing proliferation of interests, there was a sense of looking inward to a notion of what had been or should remain as the core and formative issues. Hence, the intensity over the query for moorings, the reassessment of histories and the challenge of the present and what might lie ahead. In perusing any of the numerous accounts, key questions invariably emerged. As cultural studies traveled, was there something to fix and pin down? Was there something that had to be firmly known and reached through a strategically efficacious focus? Were aspects of the past and moments of inception no longer relevant? If consensus and focus were not available – or at least not generally shared – would the present turmoil with which cultural studies was associated doom its future? Should cultural studies resist being held too rigidly, so as to avoid the intellectual closure of a discipline? Should cultural studies accept multiple angles – and the coinciding notion of pluralist unraveling – in the spirit of multiplying interests and topics? Should some domains be given far more importance than others – and if so, always, or just in certain circumstances? Which, if any, key factors or concepts should retain their urgency and gravity? The strains in the various writings published in Cultural Studies – marvelous, actually, when we re-read this text today – suggest more a creative, critical and valuable self-conscious cacophony than a useless cartography.

In the fervor of intellectual expansion and the flurry of topical proliferation, one of the strongest criticisms was that cultural studies was being ‘incorporated’, ‘commodified’ and ‘institutionalized’: terms that signaled with negative apprehension a creeping condition that purportedly came with cultural studies’ acceptance in the American academy. There were numerous criticisms for things going awry. A common argument was aimed at text-centric approaches in literary studies (the autonomy of texts as the unconscious and transcendent literary moment kindred to the autonomy of culture). In the early 1980s, literary studies could ponder the American literary theorist Stanley Fish’s influential question: ‘Is there a text in this class?’ Cultural studies had altered this proposition a decade earlier: ‘What does a text have to do with class?’ The inversion was not unusual or theoretically novel. In some ways the criticisms leveled at approaches that embraced literary autonomy – which had its roots in the post-Leavis and new criticism critiques – boiled down to the notion that the problem of class was being usurped by classrooms that dealt only with texts. The seminar room walled off society. There was, after all, an early concern in British cultural studies to transcend the separation between education and publics: this took the form of adult education (an engagement initiated by Leavis and carried forward by both Williams and Hoggart). Over time, higher learning had become severed from working-class and middle-class communities. Reinvigorating and carrying forward this tradition meant that popular knowledge and practices rooted in historical struggles ought to be challenged through a critical rethinking of strategies aimed at adult education. What should a contemporary cultural pedagogy seek to accomplish? As was often the case in adjudicating politics and the academy, such concerns came with the tension of seeing cultural studies as offering a politically focused sensibility, on the one hand, and as a flexible and supple enterprise, on the other.

The initiating impulses behind cultural studies certainly included a strong focus on confronting the problems of capitalism and class formation: these were always central concerns in the widest reaches of western Marxism and refracted in founding arguments and writing in British cultural studies. However, there were new intellectual irruptions which had nettlesome relations with the mold of class, and which were not easily reducible to class. The problem of ‘race’ and gender soon challenged the more general categorical imperatives of a Marxian legacy so deeply centered on class and political economy. Stuart Hall’s reflections on cultural studies, published in Cultural Studies, recalled the conflict between general theoretical work and the ‘interruptions’ of theoretically marginalized subjects of gender and ‘race’, as both social categories forced a reconfigured understanding of power, politics and hegemony (Brunsdon, 1996; Hall, 1992). His language captures the sense of how these two issues appeared to classical Marxism as if from outer space, and outside the established problems of theory more broadly. The concern was not about discovering ‘race’ or gender, but rather of acknowledging the insurgency of a social problem that was critically recognized already, yet largely eclipsed by the received canonical emphasis on class. Here it is crucial to note that the complications reflected early on in the expansion of problems taken up by British cultural studies were symptomatic also of the intellectual and social tensions that were well underway in the USA. The theoretical agonisms introduced by the problems of ‘race’ and gender were deeply grooved in the politics of academia already, and they emerged to problematize the near-ontological notion of class. Such shared tensions mark mutual developments within British cultural studies and American social conflicts at the moment in which cultural studies was being assimilated by American thinkers.

These observations open up the need to reflect on the larger context in which a confluence of issues, problems and interests shaped the period in which cultural studies became important in the USA. Reviewing some of these developmental ties – or ties to developments – offers a more nuanced sense of history. Exploring this juncture allows us to rethink the criticism leveled at the incorporation of British cultural studies, as it was being dislocated and relocated within a shifting American setting.

sec.title: Cultural studies in medias res: American antagonisms
sec.p: There was much that was unique and remarkable in the emergence of British cultural studies that came with internal developments. Embedded peculiarities are not so easily amenable to simple export. Cultural studies in Britain had its gravitational impulses in its formation, with intellectual sensibilities kindled and grounded as well within an actual location. The CCCS was an existing center which had a location in Birmingham. From the outset, British cultural studies also had the benefit of leadership, both administrative and intellectual, but also relied on significant collective (even if at times contentious) work, and could avail itself of the concentration that came in having its own social–local presence. The moniker ‘Birmingham School’ indicated a place of association and work, an actual point of intellectual production, of face-to-face coordinated or battled interests, a distinctive orientation, a body or school of thought (although in some accounts this latter term was resisted) and an intellectual impulse – but not to be equated with a ‘discipline’ as traditionally conceived.

Immediately crucial is the fact that cultural studies in the USA would never even come close to realizing and achieving the organizational and operative working milieu that developed in Britain’s CCCS. The sense of consolidation and compressed gravity that the CCCS could claim did not export well, and other key factors impacting its assimilation were determinate. Indeed, a somewhat reverse or inverse mode of development continued (which I shall note below). Yet, there were many developments shared between the USA and Britain that shaped cultural studies and which help to account for its resonation and value for intellectual struggles within academe. It is worth bearing in mind the complicating moments already noted in reflexive histories of the CCCS, in which ‘race’ and gender emerged to problematize the already salient role of class. These additional concerns coincided with and impacted many of the analytic domains so important to the applications and elaborations taking place within cultural studies, as it analyzed subcultures, popular culture, music, mass media and communication and literature.

In the American case, the moment of assimilating cultural studies had its own immediate history in which the academy was being impacted by a combination of demographic and political mobilizations that had grown out of the larger political culture of the Civil Rights Movement. Such pressures would transform certain teaching and administrative aspects of universities and in tandem with new curricula (pedagogical program developments), new personnel (hiring a new generation of faculty) and a changing student body (expanding outreach to minority ethnic students and women). Thus as cultural studies was experiencing a deepening, broadening and expanding range of problems, it also was being exported into an American context with its own distinct social and political struggles. In retrospect, the absorption of cultural studies into the academy and the agitation for a broader inclusion of marginalized racial groups and women were connected through an ethos of liberalized educational rehabilitation. However, the tensions being brought into the university had had a significant running battle well before American intellectuals enlisted cultural studies. These issues coincided with significant social groups that sought both presence and representation within higher education. They also brought with them a critique of the university’s long-established posture of benign neglect – of scholars who, in their intellectual work, were emerging to represent the racial and gendered margins and such scholarship’s marginalized demographic corollary in the form of hitherto-excluded populations.

Some recall of events – which are also developments – is helpful. It was due to the legacy and agitation of the long Civil Rights Movement that came to a crescendo in the 1960s that the American academy began to admit and incorporate ‘race’, gender and sexuality into various aspects of curricula, although with discernable unease, unevenness and hesitation. This milestone came on the heels of a century-long struggle after the abolition of slavery in 1865. In the opening pages of Souls of Black Folk (1903), W.E.B. Du Bois asked the question of being black: what does it mean to be a problem? The entrenchment of deep racial divisions persisted over the next six decades until the antagonisms turned into the most powerful social movement on American soil in the 20th century. Nearly a half-century after Du Bois posed that question, the Swedish social scientist, Gunnar Myrdal, was enlisted to carry out a thorough study of black–white relations in the USA. The result was the massive two-volume study entitled The American Dilemma: the Negro Problem and Modern Democracy ([1972]1944). W.E.B. Du Bois had published already his magnum opus, Black Reconstruction in America (1935), a painstakingly thorough analysis of the fate of black Americans after slavery was abolished. Du Bois tracked the contours of the progressive political disenfranchisement of African Americans and their enclosure within debt peonage in the American South. A skilled social scientist, and neither black nor American, Myrdal had been selected by the Carnegie Foundation for his presumed national neutrality. Recognizing himself as a ‘European’ and a ‘foreigner’, who was asked to take the lead in studying America’s deepest domestic crisis, the ‘Negro problem’, Myrdal carried out one of the era’s most extensive evaluations of the country’s deeply entrenched racism. Myrdal noted how overwhelmed he felt in taking on the work, not having
support from the social scientists then working in the field of race relations, whose views in the main were more static, fatalistic and, more particularly, lacking in an appreciation of the importance for social change in the moral, ideological and political forces in the nation … I was shocked and scared to the bones by all the evils I saw and by the serious political implications of the problems which I could not fail to appreciate from beginning. (Myrdal, 1972[1944]: xxv)

Twenty years after Myrdal’s massive indictment of the failure of American democratic liberalism, the long-simmering frustration and anger among black Americans erupted in numerous cities. The mid-to-late 1960s were marred by violent responses to civil rights protests and the escalating frustration and bitterness culminated in major urban conflagrations. Significant bloodshed followed many of the pitched street battles (‘riots’ in the terminology of media reportage), with black Americans frequently dying at the hands of law enforcement officials. The decade also included political assassinations of national magnitude: President John F. Kennedy (1963), Medgar Evers, Field Secretary for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (1963), Malcolm X, author and founder of the Organization of Afro-American Unity (1965), Robert Kennedy, US senator and candidate for Democratic Party presidential nominee (1968), and Dr Martin Luther King, major leader of the Civil Rights Movement (1968). There were other killings of non-elites associated with racial conflict.
