The middle of the decade also saw the irruption among white college students who launched the Free Speech movement in 1964 on the Berkeley campus of the University of California. Unlike black Americans, these students were anchored in the privilege of higher education. However, as the war in Vietnam escalated and spilled over into the larger Indo-China arena, students quickly learned that desire to contest the dominant political culture would be met with harsh repression. Although different in many socio-economic, demographic and racial aspects, both movements shared a fundamental recognition that the American polity was intolerant of substantive challenges.

Such upheavals remained as fresh and unhealed scars seared in the American body politic when universities began to feel the political pressures of the Civil Rights Movement. In 1968–1969 students at San Francisco State University launched a major strike against the institution. The strike quickly took on national significance, as strikers demanded an end to the Vietnam War and demanded the development of ethnic studies courses. These combined demands represented new and critical linkages between aspects of an unpopular foreign policy abroad and domestic pedagogy at home. It was a very unusual development as a youth movement that quickly formed alliances with the Civil Rights Movement and the anti-war movement. It was unprecedented also in that it initiated the emergence of social subjects who were asking to be brought – as subjects and as subject matter – into the academy.

More institutional challenges and conflagrations would soon take form. Three key initiatives, each aimed at the academy, were launched in 1969. The ‘Plan de Santa Barbara’ written at the University of California, Santa Barbara, was a manifesto arguing for the formation and implementation of a Chicano studies program – the first of its kind in the USA. That same year, a black studies department was officially formed at San Francisco State University and an ethnic studies department was launched at the University of California, Berkeley (which later became the nation’s first PhD program in comparative ethnic studies). The following year, the first two women’s studies programs in the USA were established at San Diego State College (which became San Diego State University) and at the State University of New York-Buffalo. As the Civil Rights Movement in the USA spread to encompass a host of new subjectivities, gender was included (or more appropriately, retrieved), and was encoded in the important proposed Equal Rights Amendment to the USA Constitution of 1972. This further invigorated egalitarianist pressures, which grew into a significant political force and a re-energized Women’s Movement. These developments, although socially broad, had a major impact upon the American university system, which responded partially by incorporating multi-racial, multi-ethnic and feminist, gender and sexuality dimensions into curricular accommodations. By the early 1970s, this new melding of institutions and social groups became associated with the term ‘multiculturalism’, which was also being adopted in various ways, in some cases as formal policies, in many European countries as part of the more transnationally diffused liberal–managerial framework for brokering the rapidly expanding tensions of social heterogeneity that grew out of old colonial vestiges as well as new immigration and diasporic flows.

However, to underscore the importance of American demographic complexities: it is no accident that the State of California would register such an academic crisis and become a key flashpoint for confronting the inegalitarian operations of higher education. The State of California was not unique with regard to exclusionary practices. However, its demography was too crucial not to harbor developing social tensions. With its vibrant history as having once belonged to Mexico (but annexed with the 1846–1848 war with Mexico), California already had a deeply embedded Mexican American population that grew significantly throughout the 20th century. California and the western American states also had numerous Native American populations, long a magnet for early American anthropological research launched by Boasian ethnology. With its location on the Pacific Rim, California also emerged as a nationally important agricultural region, relying as early as the mid-19th century upon waves of immigrant labor from Asian-Pacific regions, especially from China, Japan, the Philippines, Korea and India. This early reliance on Asian–Pacific agricultural laborers shifted to Mexican-drawn workers after the Second World War, which concentrated and demarcated a large racialized labor force based on Mexican-identified populations – it was in the agricultural fields of California that the United Farm Workers Movement took hold – thus inaugurating a deeply structured reliance that continues into the present and is constitutive to both the US political economy and its on-again/off-again floating hostility toward immigrant communities (immigration remains one of the most wrenching policy issues to date).

The university systems in California, already the largest public institution of higher education in the world, began to accommodate the political-demographic changes. By the mid-1970s numerous ethnic studies initiatives began to surface. First to develop were stand-alone special topics and courses, which occurred at the behest of singular pedagogical initiatives; then came programs which organized pedagogical offerings through a more consistent, if not routine approach, but which, like stand-alone courses, remained vulnerable to the mix of instructor availability coupled with negotiating the blessings or rejection by institutional administrators; and eventually legitimized departments emerged, which offered intellectually sustained modes of intervention, a systematically conceptualized curriculum and a sense of an achieved field of knowledge. In the structure of the university, departmental status – at least in public institutions – offered greater freedoms protected by faculty governance. Colleges and universities began to move toward engaging and including marginalized subjects (subject-matter as conceptual content as well as demographic subject-groups).

Cultural studies would soon enter the American academy at a time when political accommodation was being extended to mitigate tensions in academic contestations involving ‘race’, ethnicity and gender, and with sexuality beginning to be incorporated with the coming ascent of feminist theorizings. These developments were important and signaled historically new relations between the state and racial and gender exclusion. In the USA it was marginalized groups that fought for the right to enter the academy and to have some recognized place – to be incorporated into the body politic with rights and access to education. This struggle epitomized the current moment in a complex national and increasingly transnational juncture. Again, the political spirit was steeped in the legacy of the Civil Rights Movement and its recent history of mass public violence, bloodshed and elite and political assassinations. In this juncture large and powerful social, political and cultural conflicts had kindled a large sector of youth who held critical views of domestic and foreign policy while embracing a politics of justice and inclusion in academia. For the more marginalized minorities, incorporation was not regressive; it meant something quite different for those who had long felt disenfranchised and who sought to belong to and receive benefits from the larger ‘Great Society’: the term given to the reforms following the Kennedy presidency that addressed racial inequality and anti-poverty programs launched by President Lyndon Johnson. Gaining access to colleges and universities was an important partial resolution to what had been so chronically unattainable.

In its inception, ethnic studies drew initially on intellectual and ideological frameworks that represented a blend of cultural nationalism and political economy. These critical dispositions refracted already established and influential currents associated with self-determination movements fueled, in part, by the decolonization politics that took place as major European nations relinquished overt colonial relations, especially in Africa. Decolonization abroad fostered a politically charged rhetoric that reverberated with, and was transposed upon, the grammar of domestic struggles in the USA, and which fed into the American Civil Rights Movement. This accounts in part for why the content in the earliest stages of pedagogy in the university centered on renarrativized histories that situated racialized groups and peoples within the interpretive contexts of economic and political domination. Over time, the pedagogy would expand to reflect interdisciplinary developments, with larger ethnic studies programs and departments emulating curricula that resembled a broader liberal arts profile, achievable since the faculty servicing them received its training in various humanities and social science disciplines. The convergence of such interests within a single program often resembled the open breadth of cultural studies and the latter’s attempt to integrate work from different disciplines. However, from the outside and over time, often the identification of ethnic studies and women’s or feminist studies in the USA was seen axiomatically as sites for ‘identity politics’, a term that unfortunately conflates aspects of historically inescapably structuration with racial and gender solipsism.

The new programs and established departments that began to accommodate hitherto marginalized subjects worked in kindred ways with cultural studies. The key observation offered here is that cultural studies entered the American academy after major institutions already had begun to assimilate ethnic studies and women’s studies. Both of these academic enterprises, with roots in antagonistic social movements, harbored intrinsic criticisms of dominant disciplinary profiles of the academic world and brought issues that were intrinsically cultural in the form of counter-interpretations to critical-revisionist histories, retrieved cultural practices, community studies, expressive arts and struggles to wrest a critical understanding of the contours, often imposed from the outside, upon shifting notions of subjectivity. All of these interests aimed to impact and alter the academy’s discursive terrain and curricular offerings. In the case of ethnic studies programs, their emergence and presence varied according to regional-demographic urgencies and pressures: California’s role was not accidental or arbitrary, but situational, historical and demographic.

Gaining access to the university was inseparable from modes of arguments and advocacy. As with any viable political posture, such advocacy operated around provisionally defined relations of subjects, practices, institutions, histories and social structures. Ethnic or racial studies and feminist studies were constitutively enabled and shaped in a context that struggled with the tensions of what Gayatri Spivak (1987) called ‘strategic essentialism’: seizing upon a provisional identity relevant to political struggles and social movements that is likely to be efficacious in achieving desired goals. In this regard, identity was not about some transcendent wholeness coterminous with ontogenetic truth, but – to recall Foucault – about achieving truth effects, or what can be truly affected, brought into being, the result of accomplishing desired outcomes. From this perspective, it is understandable that the initial struggle to gain access to dominant institutions relied politically on frameworks tending toward aggregated and unified identities. However, over time, such strategic essentialism would become increasingly problematic as differences and fissures emerged, opening the door to more complex analyses of pluralized forms of racialization and gendering as both moved into new analytic fronts.

By the early 1990s, earlier essentialist and unified identities anchored in ‘race’ and gender were morphing into complex dimensions, as attention shifted toward the more difficult work of grasping and analyzing identity as a sociocultural and historical articulation. Identity became less assumed and increasingly interrogated and problematized in critical approaches: an orientation encouraged by poststructuralist theory and the emphasis on the role of discursive practices and discursive formations. Earlier social and historical gravities that anchored identity-centered stakes were uprooted in moves away from notions of fixed identities, toward challenges that attempted to get at the knowledge epistemologies behind socio-historical categories. This pushed identity and subjectivity increasingly toward postcolonial-inflected theories of fluidity and hybridity. If the earlier politics of identity derived political viability on the basis of solidarities in the face of exclusion, the morphing of identifications that ensued worked against earlier fixities while simultaneously proposing the new formations as both expressive of new conditions of social life and as new intellectual and academic currencies. By the mid-1990s a dualistic set of analytical accents were clearly discernable and somewhat reflective of the generational shifts unfolding within changing analytical orientations. On the one hand, the legacy anchored in earlier identified formations so central to the rights struggles and crucial to academic inclusion persisted, but alongside the theoretical unraveling of the identitarian paradigms which had been so central in previous institutional struggles.

However, to set aside dependency on abstract poststructuralist and postcolonial accounts: the idea of strategic essentialism gets at something that is not at all esoteric and abstract, nor requiring jumping through more recent theoretical hoops. It flags aspects of politics that actually seem basic, pedestrian and fundamental. Strategic essentialism may be restated as a way of advancing the provisionality required to battle things out and hopefully to get somewhere or something. It is about how to maximize the benefit of conditions. I do not wish to trivialize these struggles, for they are extremely urgent for those who come to things from the disadvantage point of being crushed in choice, stripped of chances and denied fundamental mobility. Such conditions are not moral fictions. Strategic essentialism, brought down to flesh and blood, involves the subjective mobilization – be it singular or group or collective – of sentiments, ideas, feelings, arguments, memories, emotional intensities, situated lives in historical limitations. It lives in a grounded and compelling sense to bring what is needed and desired into what is tangible – what Marx meant by the term ‘realize’– to make something real, in an actual-material sense in one’s life that hitherto was not there. To realize is, in essence, to see through the change of lived conditions. It hinges on attainment. From this perspective, such strategies always involve people in purposive enactments. It is the very stuff of politics, from the mundane to the grand. If birds fly and fish swim, then we could say that human beings strategically essentialize. It is surely convenient; it may be inescapable.

It is an irony in the height of theorizing – after postructuralism – that something so basic and manifested time and again in countless cases throughout human history, is pivoted upon and becomes both explanation and justification. First, as the manifestation of need and desire, then attributed to subjectivity and identity, then reassessed as performativity, then opening up as various actions that run the interpretive gamut from the theoretically logical, to the esoterically anguished, then dismissed as excessive blunder under the increasingly shriveling function behind the term ‘identity politics’ – and then put to intellectual rest as grievance studies. Notwithstanding all this, strategic essentialism has enabled achievement: subjects became present in the American academy who simply were not there before, who wrenched out of exclusionary institutions new places and positions on behalf of seeking certain desired outcomes. It is impossible to imagine American universities moving toward the inclusion of marginalized subjects, had the latter not marshaled the merged foci that highlighted political desire with institutional criticism – which came in the form of so-called strategic essentialism.

The developmental politics of inclusion would continue to unfold and become entwined in complications and contradictions. In some cases, positions won invariably would give way to new theorizing that unfixed and transcended earlier identity formations. If history was the font of discursive formations that ‘set up’ identities, which could be critically grasped as moral and political fictions, then why not take matters into one’s own hands and remake one’s self accordingly – and thus, according to what? No matter how the problem of performativity is broadly or narrowly conceived, ultimately it is a historical one, and cannot escape being a phenomenologically situated act – hence the nagging analytical questions apply. Under what conditions is a performance a mimetic act that bears unconsciously the unthought unreflexivity of the moment? To what extent is it an uncritical manifestation of the formation in which it obtains its dramaturgical grammar? When is a performance able to rupture rather than reinforce (whether playfully or antagonistically) received traditions, and succeed in bringing about new spaces for what may eventually be transformative? Put this way, the problem highlights the way that urgencies for political expediency, and/or a frenetic and frantic search for a fix – with no guarantees – in the face of unrelenting forces of upheaval and unfixing, are not easily grasped. The radical deconstruction of identity as the symptom of discursive formations and practices, and thus historical in its temporality rather than essential, also produced disparate results that could run the gamut from the critical deployment of collectively strategic identities to the distrust and dismantling of any tendencies toward the solidification of identity, to an autonomy-insistent sense of license to seize and self-fashion idiosyncratic identities in the spirit of performative do-it-yourself enactments.

With these developments in mind, two aspects need to be grasped. First, the historical process that began with crucially substantive social movements and which came to include modes of engagement, became affiliated with cultural studies, and these developments are very complex and diverse. Second, the examples that arguably are most removed from collective actions as well as social and historical engagement, and which are quickly identified in the shriveled and most dismissive meanings attributed to identity politics, are what critics of cultural studies frequently seize upon to indict the entire intellectual project. In this regard, conservatives and Left critics of cultural studies sometimes roll out arguments that echo one another.

The train I have been tracking – from social movements to institutional confrontations and assimilations to a deepening sense of identity crises, which appear to culminate in the proliferation and, at times, the conflation of subjectivities and intellectual subject matter – is not disconnected from the parallel developments of cultural studies as an ideational movement that found new institutional settings and then became enmeshed in the diffusive context of the USA. The critical view shared by the Left and the Right often centers on identity politics. For the Left, identity politics is exaggeratedly conflated with cultural studies’ abandonment of the centrality of class: it grounds identity politics as the failure to deliver a larger common-critical orientation. However, this critique is often shorn from the historical nexus of social movements noted earlier, or it selectively embraces some movements at the dismissal of others – a move also refracting emergent notions of identity. For those who had, and still have, the intellectual luxury of dismissing the sense of underlying crises of identities that came unexpectedly (and still comes) with such historical ruptures, and who are not compelled to share in empathetic dialogue, all this remains simplified in the aberration of ‘identity politics’. For the Left, the fault of dispensing with class led to class-disabled fictions that are reflected in opting for improperly grounded cultural crises. For the conservatives, it was the problem of fictitious classifications both artificial and contrived: they imposed unnecessary cultural divisions antithetical to a presumably unified body politic preferably understood as classless. In sum, the errors at hand were the result of either not enough class or too much classification. However, taken together, what flows from these assessments is a fundamental warrant of attack on cultural studies: it promoted a runaway culturalism.

Yet, identity politics is also quite open to criticism. Inasmuch as identity struggles are rooted in and owe much to the major social movements that unfolded in the 1960s, there were tangents that did and do still culminate in the evacuation of history: a naive obliviousness to structures that remained present even if not on one’s horizon, and to operating under an eclipsed sense of limits and constraints that remained with formidable problems of politically and economically ossified forms of power. Identitarianism shorn from a critically engaged awareness of socially contingent relations could appear preferred enclosures, where autonomy and separation were ultimate virtues. Understandably, such peripheral edges and marginal moments would garner serious criticism, mainly from the perspective of political ideals (e.g. membership and participation in ongoing social movements).

Such criticism can run the risk of misplaced concreteness, in associating the shallowest forms of identitarianism and kindred attention around cultural trivia with the theoretical center of cultural studies: a common critique for both disappointed Left-lamenters and Right-detesters of cultural studies. For the Left, this entails an imagined ideal of a unified front awaiting the return of troops who happened to go astray, who ought to shake off political irresponsibility and come back to rationality by merging with common progressive politics and returning to their a priori class location. For conservatives, identitarian splintering was sheer manipulation masquerading behind political correctness. In either case, seen from the outside, identitarianism was a politically confused aberration.

However, it could be argued that more forces were in motion and involved developments stretching beyond disgruntled politics. Such struggles also signified a culture undergoing conditions that arguably fostered the proliferation of identity options that emerged in tandem with societal processes that were increasingly speeding up, thus destabilizing all hitherto received and taken-for-granted conditions, eroding yesteryear’s neat binaries, making more fluid previously fixed social locations and resulting in dislocating just about any identity construction. Identitarianism colluded and collided – constitutively – in a culture that was increasingly incessant in teasing out more and more niches for psychic redemption, offering a sporadic proliferation of symbolic placeholders (the post-war consumerist cornucopia being one of these fronts) to ease the relentlessness of larger social upheavals and transformations well underway. All this remained the source of nagging attention demanded by ever-expanding pressures of the popular, and this was beginning to be noted anew by cultural studies, as charted in the work of Dick Hebdige. Such categorical imperatives could run the gamut from the playful as well as deadly serious performativity of moral fictions in search of realizing something, to inescapable constrictions (which were, and remain, often inseparable). What was emerging was an expanding critical-theoretical context in which older, ossified subjectivities and identities that embodied the fated mixture of essentialized as well as historically overdetermined identities – including but not limited to class, and largely shaped by repressive social structures – came progressively into situated contact with new theoretical reconfigurations. Many of these developments were put into practice through provocative dialogic relations between ethnic studies, women’s studies and cultural studies. Intellectual and analytical segregationists aside, the nexus facilitated a host of new fronts, critiques and reassessments that struggled to come to terms with the social and cultural (e.g. historically institutionalized) logics of the past.

The issues I have raised are important to keep in mind, as they shaped the very formation of the relations between American social movements, the rise of ethnic and women’s studies and the ‘import’ of British cultural studies. It is ironic that cultural studies was being criticized for being ‘incorporated’, for losing its original punch and succumbing to a watering down of verve, engagement and intellectual efficacy. The question of incorporation takes on a different inflection when we puncture the romanticist autonomy that never was core to cultural studies; cultural studies in Britain also was an institutionally affiliated form, nonetheless struggling within a historical moment in a crisis-ridden social formation. This is certainly the case in the American context. As Michael Denning has noted, ‘if we are incorporated in the university, it is because we are living in a corporation, not because conflicts and struggles have given way to “guilt and alienation”’ (Denning, 2004: 146).

What matters, beyond the Sender→Receiver model, is not so much the issue of cultural studies crossing the Atlantic and becoming something different – along with the awareness that it might lose its vital élan in mid-passage. What matters more is the deeper relations between historical forces, social transformations and the array of socially specific ruptures which have conditioned and contextualized the relevancy and efficacy of critical ideas and their transposition and fit. The agonistic social movements that preceded cultural studies’ incorporation helped in a major way to soften up the academy for cultural studies. Social conflicts, interjected into the university, made such an adoption possible. When the major social movements began to ground themselves in American academia, their intrinsically counter-oppositional sensibilities translated into intellectual content and immediately became linked to cultural issues. What developed were new modes of expressivity and representation emergent in literary and cultural retrievals, a desire to recollect collective histories and the work of inscribing the new subjectivities – of groups beginning to write themselves actively into the hitherto guarded canons of social and cultural knowledge. Frankly, that these subjects were allowed to write – even if from the outside their writing was not quite right – is far more socially significant than the errors associated with failing to immediately in joining the rank-and-file in class struggles and for failing to conform to already hardened cultural categories. The short-circuits and conflation of problems performed a particular kind of cultural work that filled in for not fully grasping and holding in critical play the tension that Williams argued for: the need to understand the constitutive ties between projects and formations.

What about this notion of ties? Let us return to the problem of the major social movements, as the ties between projects and formations are not readily evident, and there is always the problem of missing the connections that matter most. I can only suggest aspects of these ties and apprehend them in their partiality. I will sketch some general problems and then follow this with more specific observations that apply to disciplinary domains.

The context in the USA that favored the reception of cultural studies had much in common with that which fostered British cultural studies. There was a long and contentious history of labor struggles: Cold War politics induced forms of domestic repression and subordinated the needs of various publics to a narrow culture of conformity, which would wear thin in the post-war years; and issues of ‘race’ and gender egalitarianism challenged the rhetoric of liberal democracy (and the fundamentalism of economic reductionism). The expansion of mass media restructured the ideological terrain and introduced the antinomies of corporate enclosures as well as new modes of contesting the latter. Forms of popular culture took hold among working class youth, and antagonisms in competing uses of social science highlighted a growing critique within the social-managerialism of normative expectations through a critically insurgent perspective on deviance and delinquency – the de-demonizing of delinquency and crime. All of these were shared between the USA and Britain.

More specifically in the USA, the Civil Rights Movement, anti-war movement, women’s movements and the youth movement enabled an intellectually widening interest in critical social, political and cultural theory. As noted, the institution of higher education became a focal point for brokering social tensions. Social groups able to gain access to higher education brought certain needs and demands to academia, and cultural studies became part of the social matrix in which social struggles merged with educational reform. In this context, the notion that cultural studies was meant to be more than an academically centered practice – whether plausible or not – nurtured the lament over its incorporation and commodification.

However, there was actually little substance in the notion that cultural studies had lost its traction because of its university affiliation. On the contrary, cultural studies could become meaningful in and through its absorption and uneven assimilation into the various pockets of interests that the university provided. What else was there for cultural studies? It was not an autonomous social moment. Social moments, even if they appeared inchoate, often had focused and strategic goals to achieve. Moreover, the raging social movements did not need cultural studies. Social and political struggles did not require the high and refined theoreticist debates that juggled the pros and cons of western Marxism, the intense dialogic exchanges of paradigmatic confrontations, or the ponderings of whether actually existing interdisciplinarity was being achieved. Indeed, the reverse seems much more plausible. Cultural studies could take hold because it could rely upon social ferment that was spilling into the university, from where it could establish bulkheads and build from such.

Far more significant than identity issues, cultural studies would become enmeshed relationally with the historical dynamics that were reshaping higher education in the USA. In this regard, cultural studies drew upon as it also fed into the intellectual and academic arena. Indeed, the academic matrix infused cultural studies with the conditions of its intellectual acceleration. In the American context this acceleration unfolded not in concentrated and discernable gravity (a feature that CCCS could better symbolize, if not totally claim), but in uneven and unpredictable diffusion. Such diffusion was another source of the Left lament, and it made things harder for conservatives to track as well – although the latter did its best through the National Association of Scholars, whose spokespeople were, and remain, ready to indict the liberalist aberrations diffused throughout academe. Criticism of its incorporation implied an autonomy that it never had. Lament aside, the project of holding theory and politics in tension had its possible achievement in the terrain of intellectual struggle, and this took place in the sphere of education in both Britain and the USA. Cultural studies was possible as a constitutively formed intellectual struggle. This is not to say that it did not have important relations with popular (non-academic) struggles in adult education in the British context, and social moments in both Britain and the USA. The social milieu that these developments helped to shape privileged the reception of cultural studies.

Arguably, cultural studies was enabled by societal struggles and thus able to enter and even inhabit intellectual and academic terrain because of such movements. This development is larger and far more significant than the frustration that came to conflate institutional engagement with political regression (a progressive indictment of original sin). This was matched with the nostalgia, lament and romanticist pining for the ever-fleeting genuine subaltern (again, the challenge reappeared to be from which of the many subaltern subjects to choose). Given the trajectory of social movements and the new subjectivities coagulating around ‘race’ and gender that were demanding institutional inclusion, it is not surprising that the subalternity prone to political mobilization was not anchored in class identities. As noted, these were the very same issues that were being simultaneously brokered in the shifting currents within CCCS. However, more seriously: the criticism that cultural studies was becoming politically insipid amounted to dismissing an important institutional site of critical contestation and struggle over knowledge hitherto unavailable to a large array of classed, ‘raced’ and gendered subjects and numerous alliances both in and outside academe.

In their insurgent fluidity, these emergent tensions within academia provided a climate suitable to affinities for British cultural studies. Cultural issues were intrinsic to these intellectual struggles; they enabled cultural studies to have easier institutional access as a kindred project, and their relationship fostered synergistically ideational combinations with the new subjectivities that the American academy was forced to host. This historical juncture marks the moment in which ethnic studies, women’s studies and (shortly thereafter) cultural studies would intersect the academy and become academically entwined. These programmatic initiatives and their corresponding modes of critical enquiry found numerous ties and interests that fed into and drew upon each other, although not without consternation from anti-amalgamational orthodoxies. In doing so, the nexus served to empower the critique of disciplinary rigidities and fostered multidisciplinary and transdisciplinary lines of enquiry in a spirit very much like that promulgated by British cultural studies. All of this complicates the lament that cultural studies was taking a regressive turn through incorporation and commodification and tending increasingly toward cultural content – which often boiled down to a view of a waning gravity that was to anchor the issues of class, labor and political economy.

‘Incorporation’ and ‘institutionalization’ are not mere observations; they are loaded with analytical lenses and evaluative claims that already pose certain interpretations in their initiating frames. I take this angle to underscore the pre-existing affinities already in place in the formation of critical-intellectual work taking place within various academic arenas that drew upon relations with cultural studies. Such considerations enable us to get past superficial and false dichotomies and convenient binaries that simplify cultural studies in terms of its origins in crisis through ensuing relations with other contexts: a view that omits the deeper intellectual and analytical ties that cultural studies has with developments in the USA, ties that are missed from the onset. Their under-recognized absence flirts with the tendency to evacuate the crucial tension proposed by Williams: the need to hold in play the understanding of both an intellectual project and its formation, in medias res and in transformation. In what follows, I turn to opening up aspects of the context not commonly considered in the lament over the absorption of cultural studies in the USA, while continuing to hold on to aspects of a comparative perspective in the interplay between British and American cultural studies.

sec.title: Fielding cultural studies: underlying continuities
sec.p: Throughout 1980s to the 1990s, the assimilation of cultural studies took hold with young faculty and graduate students who were attempting to solidify their desired sense of incorporation. Cultural studies was drawn upon by many of the fields in the humanities, which is often noted, but it also found interest in the social sciences, such as history, sociology, anthropology, film studies, media and communications studies, and to a much lesser extent in political science, although not in economics. This interest reflected the intellectual milieu that enabled new ideas to enter the academy and fueled challenges on academic terrain to engage with the dominant narratives of civil society. Often, literary programs and disciplines were viewed as the most open to cultural studies, and received the most criticism for favoring textual analysis at the expense of social and contextual concerns. Yet the assumption that literary fields only found interest in texts and monopolized cultural studies appears to be an exaggeration. It did seem to be the case that literary studies, especially English departments, were more free to embrace and employ the term ‘cultural studies’, as did the field of communication and media studies. Arguably, these fields did not feel the terminological restrictions found in the social sciences. After all, sociology and anthropology had long claimed ‘culture’ as stock currency in their terminological capital and were presumably carrying out the study of culture all along. For these long established fields, to readily adopt ‘cultural studies’ would amount to embracing the value of a rival framework, while ceding intellectual turf to it. Whether to invoke and embrace or not, as cultural studies gained ground in American universities, virtually every discipline in the humanities and the social sciences harbored a more pronounced interest in studying ‘culture’, and the term was broadly resurrected.

In the exuberance of new horizons and the feel that cultural theorizing was being rejuvenated and again relevant, it was not unusual to find new graduate students who took quickly to Stuart Hall before having read much of anything by Marx; to Dick Hebdige but with no knowledge of Barthes; to Foucault but not Durkheim; to Derrida but not Kenneth Burke; and to Paul Willis and other British ethnographers, while oblivious to the Chicago School and its critical wing, which was so important to critical ethnography. This reflected not so much a reading dis-order, but rather an opportunity that kindled a new order of discovery being opened up by cultural studies. It was a moment that marked starting afresh and then moving outward to hitherto unknown theoretical horizons that were central to the spirit of cultural studies. These reading associations signaled something like the ‘two-step flow’ opinion trajectory that occupied mass communication researchers in the 1950s. Younger entering scholars and freshly minted junior professors could experience cultural studies’ theoretical retrievals much like the generation before them, those American college students who fueled the youthful ranks of the New Left, who caught wind of Marx and the Frankfurt School and other critical traditions through the marginalized sociologist C. Wright Mills and other disciplinary outliers.

Unlike other disciplines safe in their own modes of incorporation and boundary maintenance, the newly-formed ethnic or racial and gender and women’s studies programs and departments, and parallel explorations in emergent cultural studies programs, displayed a necessary shrewdness in grasping and understanding that their political and intellectual viability and survival as new enterprises was contingent on not replicating established disciplines and going after the formalism of theory and methods characteristic of disciplinary paradigms. Disciplinary approaches had screened out the impulses, rationale and content of the new initiatives. Emulating those disciplines would likely be redundant and invite conditions conducive to their dismissal. Strength was grasped in embracing interdisciplinarity, of bringing various approaches into conversation, of cross-readings (for and against the grain), and of seeking out provocative and profitable intellectual antagonisms. This was the very opposite of niche specialization or discipline boundary maintenance. Such intellectual commingling was a mode of query that disciplinarians, ensconced in their own intellectual property, were keen to avoid. To recall Collins’s criticism of sociology: disciplines tended toward fracturing into subfields encased in segmented specialization, with little spirit for exchange between them. Cultural studies offered an urgent and critical sensibility for recognizing and occupying the chasm – it minded the gap. This was its strength, but also the condition of its incessant vulnerability. Yet cultural studies was able to enter as well as augment ongoing struggles in the American academy. As it did, it gave additional license and resources to the new terrains of intellectual cohabitation – even as gatekeepers were ever quick to flag the new acts as misguided moments of intellectual miscegenation.

It was in this context that some in the American universities began to see cultural studies for its important intellectually strategic value. Students and younger academics welcomed the fresh critique and the attention to critical problems that came with the newly-expanding theoretical struggles taking place in British cultural studies. They were quick to grasp cultural studies’ relevance to confronting ossified institutions and entrenched and guarded epistemologies, and the intellectual and theoretical reflections that it fostered for understanding everyday life. These dispositions were aided from the margins – from ethnic studies, women’s studies and even art-orbiting aesthetic pockets – but also found confirmation in parallel sentiments within established disciplines and departments. These latter developments were also important, and their receptivity to cultural studies aided the opening of new academic fronts, even in the midst of a more generalized unease.

Not surprisingly, the expansive-oriented competitiveness of American academia soon found the new interests favorable to various forms of institutional entrepreneurialism. A parallel growth in critical journals and magazines servicing the new publishing culture took place (Denning, 2004). Some academic departments were quick to seize upon the prospects for the programmatic incorporation of cultural studies. The class, ‘race’, gender and history thematics that were being consolidated opened up their interest in the new theoretical fronts. It was not long before course syllabi spanning humanities and social science disciplines would offer overlapping readings. Much of the intellectual crossover was the inadvertent result of cultural studies and the ease with which it could be engaged by both existing and new academic programs. Cultural studies came to play a transposing role, enabling the shift of theoretical literatures and its own studies to be read in the context of another social and cultural key: of course, for some this was discord, but for those in search of additional ways to reinforce their newly-established stages in the university, cultural studies helped to harmonize their various intellectual struggles. After all, cultural studies had done the reaching out, the absorbing and brokering, mashing and melding of insights and resources that were readily available in the theoretical proliferation of post-war era western Marxism and kindred writings. This sense of openness to new intellectual vistas and to think outside the narrowed conformism of Cold War culture also owed much to the rupturing impact of the free speech and Civil Rights Movements, as both were crucial in making possible the psychically expansive capabilities to break down social and intellectual barriers.

Various academicians viewed the new current for its potential to expand intellectual production and to wrest new positions of thought and work. This development could occur in larger institutional settings where the incorporation of new readings and lines of thought cohabited with those more entrenched in the comfort of firmly established disciplines, which included those who disapproved of any such canonical tampering by undisciplined interlopers. Tolerance or rejection was not uniform; discipline-centered departments could differ significantly within various colleges and university campuses, with some welcoming the influences of cultural studies and others happy to close the borders. In some cases, university administrators saw the moment as conducive to program development and just plain good business sense: new interests, if courted properly, translated into enrollments, tuition from below and increased public budgets from above would follow. Thus the appropriation of cultural studies served numerous interests – not all of them compatible, and certainly not reducible to some kind of ideological uniformity. Were cultural studies anathema to the ideological and economic posture of higher education, it is likely that it would not have seen the light of day. However, such struggles are never neat, and as many sectors of the academy were dealing with the massive legitimation crisis unleashed by the Civil Rights Movement, cultural studies remained adept in accommodating and even thriving in some pockets of dissent. In the American context, the university system could demonstrate a peculiar dualism, harboring a contradictory strength and fragility central to capitalist-democratic liberalism: it could foster developments that threatened to bite the hand that fed it, especially if the net result could bring about program expansion.

Cultural studies found itself in this contradiction. Thus, on the one hand, any orthodoxy that harbored a monotheistic understanding of what cultural studies ‘really was’, was fated to recoil at its incorporation, especially if and when this involved the commingling and meshing of social movements, identities and frustrated sentiments, as the latter took on the messy pantheism of multiple interests, all vying for space and place in the university. From this angle, holding to any fixed definitions was tantamount to an intellectual-managerial nightmare: if cultural studies was incorrigible in Britain, it remained so in the USA, but for the altered reasons noted. Yet this multiplicity of engagements was inseparable from the moment’s broader (as opposed to enclosing) pressures. As cultural studies worked older and newer discourses into intellectually novel frameworks, it fed into a host of struggles that were unfolding in American society. In the process, cultural studies was being transformed, just as it was transforming the American intellectual juncture of the period. It did this along multiple and diffused lines of impact. It did not have a place; rather, it aided in the new placement of critical discourses in a wide array of intellectual fronts – a development arguably more important than the rise of some stand-alone department or set of programs.

Suffice it to say that British cultural studies did not make the move intact; it was retro-fitted. Cultural studies’ presumed crisis and fall from grace is a simple narrative only in some fictitious obituary. This is not to diminish certain sensibilities that register displacement, loss and nostalgia, and which turn on urgent criticism and debate about what kind of (strategically essentialist) identity cultural studies itself should best embrace. In a manner of analysis, the arguments for more or less viable postures were, and remain, contingent on how to grasp a project and its formation – situated in shifting locations and complex strands of historical conditions. The notion of cultural studies crashing on the shoals of incorporation and culturalism is just too simple, although it is a good argument for the loss of, or the strategies to retrieve, intellectual property.

If the process of enlisting and drawing upon cultural studies was not uniform, it was because it was appropriated selectively and thematically by and within varying program and departmental interest. Hence, literature departments with members already moving beyond the increasingly serious limitations of (a not so) ‘new criticism’ could find a strong ally in cultural studies. Raymond Williams’ work offered a historical analysis and sympathetic deconstruction of Leavisite literary thought and Arnoldian aesthetics, showing how criticism actually could be emancipated from an adherence to the autonomous text, which presupposed only a certain kind of legitimate reader that was capable of grasping and deciphering its inner architecture. Williams’ historical studies (especially in The Country and the City and Culture and Society) reinforced and augmented theoretically the critical angles provided earlier by the historico-literary insights of Americanists such as Kenneth Burke and F.O. Matthiessen, among numerous additional writers. The intellectual synergy aided the turn toward engaging the mode, manner and institutionalized histories that resituated literature’s constitutive ties to national and institutionalized politics. Textual analysis could be augmented with an eye for its embedded ideological functions, which meant that such analytic moves had to consider a text’s relations to other texts and contexts – the very challenge of conceptualizing formations. Thus, the British contributions of such ideology-critique could blend with an already emergent counterpart in the critical wing in American studies and its strong critical-literary tradition. In addressing the American Studies Association annual conference in 1988, the association’s president, Robert Berkhofer, pointed out that the earlier emphasis on the analysis of ‘myths and symbols’ was rapidly giving way to the new field of ideology critique and semiotics. The ‘new cultural studies’ featured prominently in this shift (Berkhofer, 1989). Seven years later, in her 1995 presidential address to the association, Elaine Tyler May was compelled to look back and take inventory of an older and deeper tradition of critical thought that had emerged in the 1930s and 1940s, with roots in socialism, labor struggles, anti-racism and sharp critiques of industrial capitalism. Referencing older and contemporary scholarship, May’s address illustrated the keen absorption of the theoretical upheavals and discoveries that thematized work being carried out in the contemporary juncture, as the field of American studies deepened and broadened a transdisciplinary integration of labor studies, cultural studies, ethnic and racial studies and women’s studies. The prominence that she gave to the struggles of groups from below pressed the importance of grounding cultural probes in their historical framework. The recuperative horizon could be read as a way to grasp projects and formations that linked to an older critical tradition within American studies and the reflexive expansion of the field, especially as it resonated with social movements and came to incorporate larger areas of social and cultural theory made possible in part through cultural studies (May 1996. Cf. also Denning 1996, and Lipsitz,1982, 2001). The ruptures in literary and historical analysis and corresponding canonical battles also provided the new opportunities for ‘minority’ (e.g. racialized and gendered) literatures to be taken seriously. Parallel to Hall’s various probes into the constitutive relations between ‘centers’ and ‘margins’, Abdul JanMohamed and David Lloyd (1987) shifted the question from historical identity to epistemological processes. The term ‘minority’ demanded being subjected to decentering criticism for its ideological complicity in shoring up an unproblematized notion of what the ‘dominant’ culture was supposed to mean through interrogating its blind spots.

In the case of the American Studies Association, the impetus for interdisciplinary scholarship was not centered on the critique and rejection of any particular discipline, but rather upon the opening up of disciplines and to acknowledge, explore and rectify intellectual and ideological blind spots; furthermore, to carry out a broader sharing of disciplined angles that could shed light on the larger critical object – that of American society itself, with the notion of ‘American’ becoming increasingly problematized over time. Similar to emerging critiques within British cultural studies around the need to unpack the term ‘Englishness’, American studies scholars also interrogated the legacies, programs and ideologies implied in the notion of ‘American’ in ways that probed the various intellectual as well as geographic boundaries implied in the term (Radway, 1999). Individual scholars were not so much implored to shed their disciplinary identifications (history, literature, etc.), theories and methods, as they were called upon to foster a critical analysis of American society by drawing broadly upon a variety of analytical approaches. The formation as well as transformation of American studies as an openly interdisciplinary orientation presented a rich set of historical, ideological, intellectual and political impulses which perhaps had more built-in affinities with British cultural studies than any other distinct discipline in the American academy. American studies in the 1970s already had developed a strong intellectual enquiry into working class cultures and labor histories, but in ways constitutive and consistent with the other intellectual developments taking place in the early 1970s: the problem of class – which was not abandoned – was complicated by the incursions of gender, ‘race’ and ethnicity in ways that British cultural studies was beginning to engage. Such expanded foci represented a major thrust of critical revisionism which embraced a return to studies of social forms, forces and conditions ‘from below’ in a manner that shared core thematics with British cultural studies and its attention to working class cultures.

The closely related field of sociology and its interest in ethnographic work also had strong interests in cultural studies. The ethnographic vein in cultural studies presents the deepest ties to American sociology, and in particular to the older legacy centered in the Chicago School located at the University of Chicago. In addition to ethnography, the Chicago School explored symbolic and performative dimension in social research. The CCCS explorations in youth, deviance, leisure and popular culture were all very close to the social domains that the Chicago strain in sociology studied. Youth, deviancy and criminology, along with dramaturgy, symbolic interaction and criminology, were perhaps the most immediately connected areas for sociologists and cultural studies ethnographers who worked the legacies of older paradigms in sociology. Embodied in British cultural studies, ethnographic reinvigoration found a relatively easy fit with the legacy of such ethno-sympathetic interests that the Chicago School had championed in its urban, racial and ethnic subcultural investigations. Birmingham ethnographies, especially those that tapped youth politics, racial signification and engendered frameworks were easily assimilated into American social science, and made their way into many required reading lists.

These analytic fronts also meshed well with post-war critical theories of criminology and deviancy that were emerging to counter the sociological dominance of Parsonian structural functionalism and normative sociology, because they were informed by this. The work in the late 1950s and into the 1960s carried out by American sociologists such as Howard Becker, Erving Goffman and David Matza, who advanced critical theories of social labelling in the fields of deviance, had challenged the political unconscious of structural functionalism and its manifestation in the dominant positivist discipline of criminology. At the time, criminology was re-evaluated for its role in masking the operations of normative power and institutionalized systems–maintenance models of social explanation. The emerging and critical ‘new criminology’ also reverberated in Britain, where American and British work was incorporated and then further radicalized through an exploration of ties between youth and authoritative definitions of deviance and crime. Shared considerations and cross assimilations formed a strong bridge between the classic work of the Americans Becker (Outsiders, 1963) and Matza (Becoming Deviant, 1969) and the work in Britain carried out by Stanley Cohen (Folk Devils and Moral Panics, 1972) and Ian Taylor, Paul Walton and Jock Young (The New Criminology, 1973). Such shared and merged views of American and British sociologists and criminologists led to a recasting of critical understanding of youth, deviancy and crime (Ferrell et al., 2008). A new and critical appreciation for youth subcultures grew directly out of this important institutional critique. This nexus of intellectual affinity work deserves to be seen as a harbinger of sorts for certain aspects of cultural studies, as it helps in our understanding of the theoretical integration of labor and culture and the importance of popular culture. Such syntheses were explored in the ethnographic work of Paul Willis’s Profane Culture (1978) and Learning to Labour (1981), and the politicized cultural aesthetics of the youth-popular that informed Dick Hebdige’s Subculture: The Meaning of Style (1979). Willis and Hebdige, along with others, helped bridge the earlier critical tradition that problematized the youth–labor–deviancy nexus with new theoretical ruptures taking place within the cultural crisis of Marxism. The new criminology also harbored theoretical affinities with the later work on racial formation, theorizing found in Michael Omi and Howard Winant’s Racial Formation in the United States (1994[1986]). Racial Formation was published in 1986, the same year as the CCCS publication Policing the Crisis. Omi and Winant noted the importance of the CCCS study. Although engaged in different national contexts, both studies signaled the growing tensions with and limitations regarding class reductionism. Racial Formation also contained numerous theoretical and analytical thematics that resonated deeply with developments taking place in cultural studies, especially with attention to notions of articulation, discursivity, racialization and the concern to bring racial projects into theoretical visibility.

As Elizabeth Long (1997) pointed out, sociology in general had marginalized the study of culture in the mid-century. However, a series of studies outside the mainstream sociological canon emerged in the mid-1950s and into the early 1960s. These studies, which we might loosely call characterological examinations of aspects of the normative or dominant culture, reflected a growing sense of unease, criticism and, in some cases, a marked dystopianism. This sensibility can be found in Sloan Wilson, The Man in the Gray Flannel Suit (1955), Paul Goodman, Growing Up Absurd: Problems of Youth in the Organized System (1962), David Reisman, Nathan Glazer and Reuel Denney, The Lonely Crowd: A Study of the Changing American Character (1963) and C.Wright Mills and Hans Gerth’s Character and Social Structure (1964). Of these writers, it was Mills who provides an interesting and intellectual link to the emergent ferment of the New Left – which was so important, as Hall recalled, to the formation of British cultural studies. Mills spent 1957 to 1958 in Oxford; he came to feel at home intellectually in Britain and considered permanently relocating there. The BBC’s magazine, The Listener, gave Mills more popular-critical attention than he could find in the USA. By the early 1960s, he had already penned several critical studies of class, politics and power in the USA. He wrote much of his classic The Sociological Imagination (1959) while he was at the London School of Economics. Mills established intellectual ties with British scholars who were affiliated with the New Left Review, and it was in that publication that Mills first published his famous ‘Letter to the New Left’ (1960). It was published again in the American Left counterpart, Studies on the Left and reprinted by the organization Students for a Democratic Society in the following year.

The importance of labor and labor histories offered another deeper connection between American social and historical studies and the reception of cultural studies. The shared reciprocity between the New Left in Britain and the USA was extended in academic history journals. American historians launched the Radical History Review in 1974; British historians inaugurated the History Workshop Journal in 1976. The intellectual camaraderie linking both journals is documented in their mutual commemoration of the life of the social and popular historian Raphael Samuel (Pfister, 1991; Dworkin, 1997). American historians paid tribute to the importance of E.P. Thompson to Marxian historical studies and, along with facets in historical sociology, the field of American studies also drew on this critical nexus. Norm Fruchter, an American who served as Stuart Hall’s assistant editor at New Left Review, returned to the U.S. where he helped in editorial work with Studies on the Left (Geary, 2008; Brewer, 2004).

The sense of popular culture having a long and entrenched relationship with the dominant culture runs deep in American society. Music, both high and popular, has been a frequent feature of this historical tension. In the American case, the challenges posed by sonic production and its constitutive relations with labor, class, ‘race’, gender and the cross-referential dynamics of subjectivities and socio-historical contexts stretch over a long critical history: from slave songs and spirituals to work songs, urban-immigrant musical retentions and their modification in sites associated with vaudeville and burlesque; the social and class aestheticism behind the bifurcation between classical and popular; the systematic de-popularizing of classical music as it was resituated in the conservatory and the university; and the insurgency of jazz and the vernaculars that inform country music to folk, rock ‘n’ roll, rhythm and blues, punk and hip-hop.

Popular music studies in the USA was divided among numerous approaches: from anecdotal to systematic formalism; from the urban and ethnographic-rooted traditions of the Chicago School, to structural functionalist orientations associated often with the ‘production of culture’ approach and a reliance on organizational and institutional sociology; with genres derived out of popular vernaculars from below, to genres produced by market monetization from above. Add to this the music-centered field of ethnomusicology, with its distinct indebtedness to the paradigms of anthropology and musicology as a discipline that primarily tracked high or art music, but which also began to expand critical interest in popular music. Popular music was crucial to the irruption of American youth in the 1950s, especially with the forms of rhythm and blues, rockabilly and rock ‘n’ roll. The centrality of popular music shifted in the mid-1960s as rhythm and blues shaded into the anger of soul and funk music in tandem with the Civil Rights Movement, and with the great popularity of British pop and rock artists, who drew heavily from American popular musical genres, especially black music. It is not an exaggeration to say that the protest movements of the era were also sonically underscored. A vast literature on this aspect of subcultures, politics and movements has since developed.

Thus, when the CCCS began to produce ethnographies that gave serious attention to popular music, carrying out connective explorations that American social scientists were not so eager to encourage, that work struck immediate chords with younger emergent students and scholars who grew up with popular music and who recognized music’s intrinsic ties to identities, institutions, politics and shifting histories. Yet when one examines the sociology of culture as a subfield in the mid-1970s through the mid-1980s, popular music study appears anemic. Instead, the sociology of culture in the USA was much more attuned to focusing on dominant political values (usually from normative-institutional perspectives, but sometimes in crisis) that were refracted in the elite arts, museums, lived modalities of urban cosmopolitanism and, of course, the ‘big’ areas of religion, ethics, politics and civic values. In the preoccupation for presumably more serious institutional sites, the popular appeared rather ‘unpopular’. Conversely, when British cultural studies fused new social theory with popular music, as did Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Ian Chambers, Simon Frith and others, their work illuminated ways in which the popular could be critically recovered. The popular-infused ethnographic work of CCCS could speak to students of popular music who were scattered across the fields of sociology, American studies, ethnomusicology and mass media and communication.

The ties between the study of popular music and cultural studies are well known. However, in musicology, the work of Susan McClary, often associated with ‘new musicology’, marked an important attempt to merge formal musicological analyses and frameworks core to cultural studies. Looking back a decade after her groundbreaking work, McClary noted that formalist-oriented musicology ‘had lost sight of cultural meanings’. The legacy of her study, Feminine Endings,
granted North American scholars license to discuss meanings and to exchange interpretations; it has encouraged the development of cultural studies in musicology; and it has made music accessible to the people working in disciplines far outside of music. (McClary 2002[1991]: xviii)

The new connectivity that cultural studies brought to music studies could resonate immediately with the entwined concerns of cultural politics, youth culture, marginalized subcultures and popular music in ways that sought to overcome the tendencies to separate the organization of social power from the phenomenology of everyday life. In so doing, cultural studies restored the hermeneutical and phenomenological dimensions of music by addressing and unpacking the ethnographic terrain of the popular aesthetic to get at formulations of meaning, thus giving music studies an angle different from the production of culture paradigm. The sociologist Richard Peterson, a key founder of the production of culture approach, was one of the first American sociologists studying music to notice and incorporate CCCS-influenced work. As Peterson accounts:
I learned a great deal from their ethnographic studies of how groups of young people take the types of commercial music on offer and reconstruct them to fit their own purposes. The 2004 anthology Music Scenes, edited jointly with the Brit Andy Bennett … is an attempt to systematically understand the context in which such grass-roots cultural formations are created and exploited. (Santorum, 2008: 43)

The hermeneutic and phenomenological dimension that British ethnographies taped reverberated with the same currents that were emergent in ethnic studies, as the latter sought modes of study that restored aspects of lived cultures and everyday life. The turn toward culture in general and popular culture in particular caught the younger intellectuals where they lived their everyday lives – culturally – in the push-and-pull of the popular. Cultural studies helped to foster new intellectual spaces for critical exploration of the popular by providing additional analytical and theoretical legitimacy to an already deeply-felt sense of what popular culture refracted and engendered in spite of its relative trivialization, if not exclusion, in academia where it was often held in disdain by scholars on the Right and Left.

The attention that cultural studies brought to media and mass communications also prodded the field of communication and media studies and re-established older and newer theoretical bridges. Interestingly, sociology once had a strong media and communications tradition, which it largely discontinued for other endeavors. Consider how early American sociology in the first half of the 20th century (rooted in the Chicago School) blended pragmatism, philosophy, symbolic interaction; journalism, newspapers, film and music; investigations into urban, ethnic and racial analysis; and youth, crime and delinquency and deviance, etc. This kind of synthetic sociology – which also championed early research in communications – was largely abandoned as sociology’s center of gravity moved to Columbia and Harvard, where the mode of enquiry favored social managerial frameworks amenable to the rise of structural functionalism and normative sociology, as the discipline became more aligned with the larger currents of Cold War society. If sociology once had strong ties to the study of mass culture and mass communication, those ties had largely frayed by the 1960s. Correspondingly, the fields of journalism ascended, along with public opinion and communications (with the latter two often associated with public relations, marketing and instrumentally hired out survey research). By the 1970s to the early 1980s, sociology and these new formalized disciplines seldom intersected (Gitlin, 1978; Pooley and Katz, 2008).

The fields of media studies and communication are important in that both hosted and were enhanced by cultural studies, which also pulled these fields, along with sociology, to begin treating popular and mass culture more seriously. Problematizing mass culture was already an issue of central concern within western Marxism’s attempt to understand the relations between structures of power, social conformity, social conflict and antagonism. The post-war juncture demanded such attention. Mass culture had become increasingly consolidated, had gained in diffusive power and emerged as an omnipresent feature in the USA, yet the analysis of its impact had become scattered and segmented into various walled-off disciplines. As noted, cultural studies refused to honor or perpetuate such boundary work in order to grasp the historically situated interplay of politics and theory beyond paradigmatic disciplines. Indeed, the fusion of media and culture, drawing firmly on sociological insights of earlier eras (the Chicago School) and insurgent theories from Europe (cultural Marxism, critical theory, semiotics and poststructuralism) were being knitted together in various patterns across British cultural studies, and in ways of problem formulation that offered key lessons to how and why such work might matter in the USA.

sec.title: To look back and forward at the same time
sec.p:
It is a misreading to see cultural studies as simply trickling in from the outside, as an export being imported and then snapped up by theoretically hungry and shrewd consumers – or worse, by dilettantes doomed to join the ranks of the intellectual manqué. Such narratives that hold this view are easily sidetracked by – and identifiable through – the energetic foci they place on the shortcomings of cultural studies. They overlook the larger social and historical context that shaped the attraction offered by cultural studies, and which helped to install the conditions of relations and the relations of conditions, as the new intellectual sensibilities took. Up-and-coming students in the USA learned from this retrieved connectivity and melded it with the historical crisis of the Cold War, the Civil Rights Movement, anti-war politics and a resurgent Women’s Movement. The problem with the critique of cultural studies being trapped and short-changed by a reductionism to ‘race’, class and gender, is that
it takes the starting point of cultural studies as its conclusion. Race, class and gender are not the answers in cultural studies, the bottom-line explanation to which all life may be reduced; they are precisely the problems posed – their history, their formation, their ‘articulation’ with particular historical events or artistic works. These are the issues to be explained and understood. (Denning, 2004: 140)

Denning is right to point out how criticism demonstrates short-circuiting by misrecognizing the conditions of its own mode of argumentation, when ‘the attempt to trivialize cultural studies by citing the worst examples of pop culture analysis is not dissimilar to the attempt to trivialize the liberation movements by citing ridiculous examples of so-called identity politics’ (2004: 150).

The short-circuits that have arisen to dismiss cultural studies, especially by dwelling on the trivial, share an alliance with views of cultural studies as a series of failures. Seeing British cultural studies only as an export has encouraged views in which it was likely to fail. As I have argued, this view assumes that cultural studies was a thing capable of traveling intact and should have taken hold in ways resembling the Birmingham School. This notion, as Hall often addressed, had its own flaws and was even doubted within British cultural studies. However, the expectation still had its adherents, and that the CCCS could not be replicated led to unavoidable disappointment; this fostered criticisms of cultural studies that eclipsed its historical juncture with intellectual and institutional developments already brokered in the American context. It was an easy move for critics to latch onto the problem of class as the missing or abandoned rationality responsible for its American failure. This ascribed identification attributed to the ‘origins narrative’ of cultural studies appears to be a latter-day preferred reading, given that the crisis of Marxism and the problem of reductionism was already a serious debate, with challenges to orthodoxy and reductionism having nearly a half-century to ground itself before the CCCS was formed. British cultural studies did not invent this tension; it inherited it along with the theoretical irruptions that it struggled to assimilate. However, in its own historically remarkable way it gathered them up, brought them into critical dialogue and sought to focus them on the interplay of history and power, structures and subjectivities – projects and formations.

The overwrought criticisms that began to gain traction as cultural studies entered the USA in medias res obscure – perhaps strategically so in a theoretically essentialist way – the historical interplay, cross-fertilization, shared historical nexus and constitutive developments at root and, thus overlook the importance of subject-centered sociopolitical movements in the USA which, I have argued, were crucial in helping prepare cultural studies’ reception in the American academic milieu. Although the criticisms of cultural studies being not Marxist enough and yet too Marxian stem from quite different political ideologies and orientations, both indulge in the obfuscation and eclipse of this historical juncture. No wonder, then, that the trivialization of cultural studies for not ‘maturing’ into something like a bona fide discipline issues from both critical and conservative quarters.

Given the very long history of theoretical irruptions, many of which were central to the formation of cultural studies, it is perplexing that the solution to cultural studies is simply to get back to Marxism – as if this is somehow a neat and simple move. Yet this appears to be one of the most recent proposals to repair cultural studies today. As Paul Smith has argued, cultural studies got in trouble in the USA because it had harbored ‘an extreme desire not to be seen as Marxist’ (Smith, 2011: 252). According to Smith, cultural studies can now be renewed: it is now in a position to retrieve its responsibilities by embracing a sober Marxism that will deliver ‘notably, the definition of the field, its assumptions, its proper objects of study and its methods and methodologies’ (3). Smith speaks of an achievement that has moved past a ‘looseness’ that is ‘wholly out of date’ due to its association with the ‘early US importers of cultural studies’ (2), in that moment when Stuart Hall was (purportedly) ‘happy enough with the idea that “no single, unproblematic definition of culture” would underpin the operation’ (2). This hasty caricaturization of Hall’s perspective aside, Smith’s view is that cultural studies at his institution is finally able to shake off its British import and get on with academic professionalism. The renewal of cultural studies, Smith suggests, is to be had by distancing itself from the errors of past disappointments. In another section of the book, Smith identifies one of the major problems that befell cultural studies:
I would identify as crucial in that narrative what I call the ‘thematization’ of cultural studies, where instead of thinking of culture as a structural phenomenon, it became a series of rote topics or themes: race, ethnicity, gender and so on. (2011: 252)

Class, of course, presumably escapes rote trappings and, with structures, survives in this renewal. This neatness and sense of resolution, along with a corresponding appeal to formalist professionalization, probably makes sense as a strategically essential move when one deals with university culture and administrators, particularly at a time when disciplines are under increased scrutiny to produce legitimate intellectual products. This position of formalized enclosure is symptomatic of the historical terrain of interpretation that I have presented. It is a perspective that hopes to salvage cultural studies by positing culture as a solely structural phenomenon that should disentangle itself from the nettlesome social subjectivities themes of ‘race’, ethnicity and gender. Cleansed of the latter, the real is again presumably ‘graspable’.

Not so benign are policies that actually take steps to expel cultural forms seen as an impediment to well-run programs. One solution, regressive in its motivations, is to simply expel the excessive cultural margins. At the time of writing, the State of Arizona recently passed legislation that withholds public funds for secondary schools that teach ethnic studies, mainly targeting Mexican-identified arenas of pedagogy. This policy decision is coupled with a call to ban books affiliated with such ‘divisive’ subject areas. These cultural conflicts have their European counterparts refracted in a pronounced unease with ‘multiculturalism’, as numerous articles in this journal have documented over the recent years.
