Abandoning class and structures is unacceptable. But we should be wary of accepting the historical amnesia that fails to grasp the interplay of historical formations and cultural projects. If the past is still in need of reckoning with, the present and future appear to yield more complexities that make it even more difficult to wish away new subjectivities by recourse to the neatness of theoretical technicism. New subjectivities continue to insinuate themselves into social and cultural developments that have become increasingly complicated within a rapidly transforming socio-historical and cultural context. We enter a world characterized by massive crises, taking the form of sprawling and hard-to-locate syndromes of violence along with ossified regimes of state violence; the rapid decomposition and reconstitution of functions of governmentality as well as structures of capital; religious apocalyptic views that seek to be realized; and technocultural capacities that can immediately link millions through the structurally disembedding capacities of new social media, producing massive transnational and somewhat accidental publics that cannot be grasped simply as expressions of class, gender, ‘race’, or as organizations or institutions. These are the very conditions that easily could bring into being entirely new horizons upon which even more troubled trans-subjectivities emerge. The challenge that these new conditions pose is not that they could become the next rote topics or thematizations that might distort a preferred reading of cultural studies. Rather, they challenge the grids of formalized paradigms rooted in the previous century, as they cannot be easily placed into neat structural categories, for structures are not fixed, there to be read off as analytically evident – structures, too, undergo restructuration.

I have argued that it is important to let go of the rigidities of the ‘export’ frame – not because cultural studies was a flawed import (the conservative critique), or that its virtues were spindled in its adaptation (the critical perspective). It is because it obscures the fine-grained interplay of a deeper and shared historical juncture. The ‘export’ frame precludes an appreciation of the complex negotiations that took place as cultural studies intersected the social struggles that were being interjected into the American university, which came from American society and which spilled profoundly into the most central societal apparatus of culture and consensus: the university. In distancing ourselves from the distracting quagmire of multiple accounts of failure so common among American critics, and from the laments within the viewpoints that indict cultural studies for being a ‘Marxist failure’ (which find some Marxists and anti-Marxists in agreement), we begin to see something quite different. We see that the historically valuable work that marked the rise of British cultural studies, especially its recognition and painstaking willingness to push open a much-needed theoretical expansion that was coming into visibility after the Cold War, had great import for critical studies and had impact upon a much broader terrain. This, in itself, is a remarkable historical phenomenon.

Although cultural studies did not find itself becoming cloned neatly and quickly, its collision and collusion with the social movement-inspired transformations that were taking place and shaping the crisis of higher education in the USA remain one of the most important developments to affect critical thought in the American case. This process was not likely to revolve around a distinct program formation, method or theoretical resolution and no ‘school’, but rather in a remarkable assimilative diffusion across, and in tension with, many sectors of the humanities and social sciences. This more general development, which did not result in an intellectual-managerial formation that was ‘headquartered’ somewhere – either in a discipline or in self-appointed guardians and gatekeepers – is much more formidable than the laments and obituaries that arose and that continue to swirl about today.

Cultural studies in the USA did not develop with the same kind of autonomy, neither did it encounter the level of institutional resistance that characterized its formation in Britain. In lieu of not having a center or school to opt towards, individuals were and remain in the condition of having to incorporate cultural studies sensibilities – the meaning, forms and angles and theoretical probing that now vary widely – within and in tension with institutional and disciplinary environments. The academic environment, also the site of social antagonism, enabled intellectuals that aspired to engage with and carry out cultural studies-identified work. It was the main terrain upon which such thought and work was possible (although never limited in this manner), and such work always took hold at the edges, or in the shadow, of established disciplines that both supported and remained wary over such innovations. Individuals attempting to move forward with cultural studies often did so in the negotiation of their work with the governing paradigms of disciplinary supervision. In the American context it seems much more the case that cultural studies was actually sought and enlisted as a strategy to give academic empowerment to thought and analysis, criticism and action, both in tension with and in support of a university system conceived (even if ideally) as the site within civil society where there was a primary responsibility to enable and protect such possibilities for the development of critical thought and practice. In this vein the university could be challenged – as it has long been, with varying degrees of failure and efficacy – to fulfill its most ideologically contentious and contradictory role: wanting to promote itself as a bastion of freedom from a powerful and encircling corporatist polity and culture while also operating as a corporate entity. This is not perplexing, given that the university at present is constitutively engaged in collision and collusion with a much more powerful corporatist formation. Yet this is the institutional condition in which we carry out critical work – and, again, with a necessary feel for relations outside and beyond the academy.

Raymond Williams’ reflection on the need to hold in critical play the understanding of intellectual work and the historical terms of its formation were important in the launching of cultural studies. His advice is perhaps even more urgent in the present context, which seems to be more aggressively interested in pruning back the idealist rhetoric that pertains to liberal arts education, a luxury that crackpot pragmatism and instrumentalist market logic would rather purge. Local as well as transnational milieus today recoil in the near collapse of global capitalism’s legitimacy and the fallout that threatens to shrivel the economically precarious will to keep education as part of the social contract. The current juncture fosters the view that education needs to be remade to fit diminishing expectations of yesteryear’s notions of progress and aspiration, and as the new discipline is needed to prepare a workforce which can compete in the new global marketplace. It is an environment in which academic disciplines are increasingly viewed with regard to their questionable usefulness that was once firmly anchored in the intellectual virtues of providing citizens with fundamental exposure to education as a civic good. Behind the rationales for readjusting to these interpretations is a larger anxiety that American society is ill-prepared to examine. Up to the recent past, American culture (which is not limited to its geopolitical borders) was constituted in the spirit of governing in the globalized inequality that underscored ‘the West and the Rest’. Today, the current crisis comes with the raw anxiety of inhabiting a ‘West like the Rest’, which is not limited to the USA. Both frames are built on the shambles of a world marked by historical structures of massive inequality. The moment is ripe for panicky and defensively dystopian enclosures around critical thought, and yet it is also ripe for a reinvigoration of critical thought.

The nexus of social moments and cultural studies was not accidental: the relationships that developed were dialogic as well as constitutive. The social conflicts that preceded the assimilation of cultural studies – some of which were present in shaping cultural studies in Britain – played a major role in how distinct social, cultural and politic strands developed in their constitutive relations. Certainly, the social movements noted above were fundamental in creating new institutional space for both the emergent social subjectivities that resulted in the demographic transformation of education and, in turn, the charged urgency and relevancy of the subject matter crucial to the intellectual sensibilities fostered in cultural studies. In addition, these relationships were historically situated. Grasping the nexus not only provides some important intelligibility with regard to what happened with cultural studies and why; it also begs the problem of the present: how attuned might cultural studies be today to the social moments and movements that swirl in many places in the world? The remarkable social movements of the moment – environmental struggles, expanding women’s struggles, economic justice, mass mobilizations against political authoritarianism, communication-enabled new publics and others – raise the question: what kind of intellectually flexible mode of critically productive thought will be available to enable the much-needed comprehending, combining and juxtaposing capable of bringing new conditions (combining formations and projects) into critical visibility and dialogue? Rather than hope and wait for some existing discipline or refurbished department to rise with readiness to grant degrees, we ought to think about what it means to be able to retain and keep kindled the critical yet now diffused spirit. It may be that the diffused assimilation of cultural studies across the many disciplines and many new places in other parts of the world will have another chance to show its value.

bio.title: Biographical note
bio.p: Jon Cruz teaches in the department of Sociology at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and is a managing editor of the European Journal of Cultural Studies. He is author of Culture on the Margins: The Black Spiritual and the Rise of American Cultural Interpretation (Princeton 1999) and co-editor (with Justin Lewis) of Viewing, Reading, Listening: Audiences and Cultural Reception (1994). His current interests are in music studies and he is completing a book on music’s relationship to the digital turn and how developments in the musical sphere impact other areas of cultural production.
